DIV1.P: THE HEIR AT LAW: A COMEDY, IN FIVE ACTS.
AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, CROW-STREET, WITH UNIVERSAL APPLAUSE.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE I.—Room in LORD DUBERLY'S House.
LORD DUBERLY and LADY DUBERLY discovered at Breakfast.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD DUBERLY.
SP.P: BUT what does it matter, my Lady, whether I drink my tea out of a cup or a saucer?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: A great deal, in the polite circles, my Lord. We have been raised by a strange freak of fortune, from nothing, as a body may say; and—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Nothing! As reputable a trade as any in all Gosport. You hold a merchant as cheap as if he trotted about with his property in a pack, like a pedlar.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: A merchant, indeed! Curious merchandize you dealt in, truly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: A large assortment of articles:—Coals, cloth, herrings, linens, candles, eggs, sugar, treacle, tea, bacon, and bick dust; with many more, too tedious to mention in this here advertisement.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Well, praise the bridge that carried you over; but, you must now drop the tradesman, and learn life. Consider, by the strangest accident, you have been raised to—neither more nor less than a peer of the realm.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Well; but I han't been a nobleman more nor a week; and my throat isn't noble enough yet to be proof against scalding. Hand over the milk, my Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Hand over! oh, what's bred in the bone will never come out of the flesh, my lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Pshaw! there's a fuss indeed! when I was plain Daniel Dowlass, of Gosport, I was reckoned as cute a dab in discourse as any in our town, nobody found fault with me; my thoughts were like a fat plough▪man's chub∣by children. If folks found them fresh and strong enough, no matter how they were clothed. But people, I take it, fancy a great Lord's thoughts, are like his ricketty brats—plaguy weak, and damned ordinary; and want a deal of dressing up to make 'em pass.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: But why so loud?—I declare the servants will hear.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Hear! and what will they hear but what they know? our story a secret, Lord help you!—tell 'em Queen Anne's dead, my Lady. Don't every body know that old Lord Duberly was supposed to die without any heir to his estate—as the Doctors say, of an implication of disorders; and, that his son, Henry Moreland, was lost some time ago, in the salt sea.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Well, there's no occasion to—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Don't every body know that Lawyer Ferret, of Fernival's Inn, owed the Legatees a grudge—and pop'd a bit of an advertisement into the News? "Whereas, if the Heir at Law, if there be any reviving, of the late Ba∣ron Duberly, will apply—so, and so; he'll hear of som'ut greatly to his advantage."

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: But why, bawl it to the—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Didn't he hunt me out to secure my title? and lug me from the counter, to clap me into a coach? a house here, in Hanover-square, and an estate in the country, worth fifteen thousand per annum?—Why, bless you, my Lady, every little black devil, with a soot-bag, cries it about the streets, as often as he says sweep.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: 'Tis a pity but my Lord had left you some manners, with his money.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: He, what my cousin twenty thousand times removed, he must have left them by word of mouth.—Never spoke to him but once, in all my born life, upon electioneering matter—that's a time when most of your proud folks make no bones of tippling with a tallow-chan∣dler, in his back-room, on a melting day: but he!—ex∣cept calling me cousin, and buying a lot of damaged huck∣aback, to cut into kitchen towels, he was as old and stiff as he is now, tho' he has been dead and buried these nine months, rot him!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: There, again, now!—Rot him!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Why, blood and thunder! what is a man to say, when he wants to consecrate his old stiff-rumped relations?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Why, an oath, now and then, may slip in to garnish genteel conversation: but then it should be done with an air to one's equals, and with a kind of careless condescension to menials.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Should it?—well then—here John—

DIV2.P: my good man, take away the tea and be damn'd to you?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Yes, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: And now, my lord, I must leave you for the concerns of the day, we elegant people are as full of busi∣ness as an egg's full of meat.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Yes, we elegant people find the trade of the tone, as they call it, plaguy fataguing—What, are you for the wis-a-was this morning? much good may do you, my lady,—damn it, it makes me sit stuck up like a bear in a bathing tub.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: I have a hundred places to call at—Folks are so civil since we came up to take possession—there's dear Lady Littlefigure, Lord Sponge, Mrs. Heldbank, Lady Betty Pillory, the Hon. Mrs. Cheatwell, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Aye, aye; you may always find plenty, in this here town, to be civil to 15,000 a year, my Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Well, there's no learning you life. I'm sure they are as kind and friendly—the supper Lady Betty gave to us and a hundred friends, must have cost her fifty good pounds, if it cost a brass farden; and she does the same thing, I'm told, three times a week. If she isn't monstrous rich, I wonder, for my part, how she can afford it?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Why, ecod, my lady, that would have puz∣zled me too, if they hadn't hooked me into a damn'd game of cocking and punting, I think they call it, where I lost as much in half-an-hour, as would keep her and her com∣pany in fricassee's and whipt sullibub's for a fortnight. But I may be even with her some other a'ternoons. Only let me catch her at put,—that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Doctor Pangloss, is below, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Odds bubs! my Lady, that's the man as larn me to talk English.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Hush, consider.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Hum! I forgot—curse me, my honest fellow, shew him up stairs d'ye hear?—[exit John.]—There—was that easy?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Tolerable.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Well, now, get along, my lady. The doctor and I must be snug?—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Then, I bid you a good morning, my Lord, as Lady Betty says, I wish you a bone repos.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: A bone repose! I don't know how it is, but the woman are more cuter at these here matters, nor the men. My wife, as every body may see, is as genteel al∣ready, as if she'd been born a dutchess. This doctor Pangloss will do me a great deal of good, in the way of fashioning my discourse, so here he is,—
Doctor, good morning—I wish you a bone repos!—Take a chair, Doctor?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Pardon me, my Lord; I am not inclined to be sedentary, I would with permission, "erectos ad sidera tollre vultus."—Ovid.—Hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Tollery vultures! I suppose that means you rather stand?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Fye, this is a locomotive morning with me.—Just hurried, my Lord, from the Society of Arts; whence, I may say, "I have borne my blushing honours thick upon me."—Shakespeare.—Hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: And what has put your honor to the blush, this morning, doctor?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: To the blush?—A ludicrous perversion of the author's meaning.—He, he, he!—Hem!—you shall hear, my Lord.—"Lend me your ears."—Shakespeare, again.—Hem!—'Tis not unknown to your Lordship, and the no less literary world, that the Caledonion University of Aberdeen, long since conferred upon me the dignity of L. L. D.—and as I never beheld that erudite body, I may safely say, they dubb'd me with a degree, from sheer consi∣deration of my celebrity.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: True.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: For nothing, my Lord, but my own innate modesty, could suppose the Scotch College to be swayed by one pound, fifteen shillings, and three pence, three far∣things, paid on receiving my diploma, as a handsome compli∣ment to the numerous and learned heads of that Seminary.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Oh, damn it, no; it wasn't for the matter of money

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P:
I do not think it was altogether the "auri sacra fames."—Virgil—Hem!—But this very day, my Lord, at eleven o'clock, A. M. the Society of Arts, in consequence, as they were pleased to say, of my merits,—he, he, he!—have admitted me an unworthy member; and
I have, henceforward, the privilege of adding to my name the enviable title of A. double S.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: And I make no doubt, doctor, but you have rightly deserved it. I warrant a man don't get A. double S. tacked to his name for nothing?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Decidedly not, my Lord.—Yes, I am now Artium Societatis Socius.—My two last publications did that business.—"Exêgi monumentum aere perennius."—Horace.—Hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: And what might these two books be about, Doctor?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: The first, my Lord, was a plan to lull the restless to sleep by an infusion of opium into their ears:—the efficacy of this method originally struck me in St. Ste∣phen's chapel, while listening to the oratory of a worthy country gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: I wonder it wasn't hit upon before, by the Doctors.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Physicians, my Lord, put their patients to sleep in another manner. He, he, he!—"To die—to sleep—no more"—Shakespeare.—Hem!—My second treatise was a proposal for erecting Dove-houses, on a principle, tending to create the propagation of pigeons. This, I may affirm, has received considerable countenance from many who move in the circles of fashion.—"Nec gemëre cessabit turtur."—Virgil.—Hem!—I am about to publish a third edition by subscription. May I have the honour to pop your Lordship down among the pigeons?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Aye, aye; down with me, Doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: My Lord, I am grateful. I ever insert names and titles at full length. What may be your Lord∣ship's sponsorial and patronymick appellations?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: My what?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: I mean, My Lord, the designations given to you, by your Lordship's godfathers and parents.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Oh, what, my christian and surname?—I was baptised Daniel.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: "Ablens baptismàte lbum."—I forgot, where—Hem! The Right Honourable Daniel—(writing.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Dowlas.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: (Writing.) Dowlass.—"Filthy Dow."—Hem!—Shakespeare.—The Right Honourable Daniel Dowlas, Baron Duberly.—And, now, my Lord, to our lesson for the day..

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Now for it, Doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P:
The process which we are now upon, is to eradicate that blemish in your Lordship's language which
the learned denomidate cacology, and which the vulgar call, slip▪slop.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: I'am afraid, Doctor, my Cakelology will give you a tolerable tight job of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: "Nil desperandum." Virgil.—Hem! We'll begin in the old way, my Lord. Talk on;—when you stumble, I check. Where was your Lordship yesterday evening?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: At a Consort.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Umph! tête á téte, with Lady Duberly, I pre∣sume.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: No, tète á tête, with five hundred people, hearing music.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Oh, I conceive.—Your Lordship would say, a Concert.—Mark the distinction.—A Concert, my Lord, is an entertainment visited by fashionable lovers of harmo∣ny. Now a Consort is a Wife; little conducive to harmo∣ny, in the present day, and seldom visited by a Man of Fashion, unless she happens to be his friends or his neigh∣bours.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: A devil of a difference, indeed! Between you and I, Doctor—now my Lady's out of hearing, a wife is the devil.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: He, he, he!—There are plenty of Jobs in the world, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: And a damned sight of Jezabels, too, Doctor. But patience, as you say—for I never give my Lady no bad language. Whenever she gets in her tantrums, and talks high, I always sit mum-chance.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: "So spake our mother, Eve, and Adam heard." Milton.—Hem!—Silence is most secure, my Lord, in these cases; for if once your Lordship opened your mouth, 'tis twenty to one, but bad language would follow.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Oh, that's a sure thing; and I never like to disperse the woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Asperse.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Humph! There's another stumble!—After all, Doctor, I shall make but a poor progress in my ver∣micular tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Your knowledge of our native, or vernacu∣lar language, my Lord, time and industry may meliorae. Vermicular is an epithet seldom applied to tongues, except in the case of puppies who want to be wormed.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Ecod, then, I'ant so much out, Doctor; I've met plenty of puppies, since I came to town—whose tongues are so very troublesome, that worming might chance to be of service.—But, Dr. I've a bit of a proposal to make to you, concerning of my own family.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Disclose, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Why, you must know, I expect my son, Dicky, in town this here very morning. Now, Doctor, if you would mend his cakelology, mayhap it might be bet∣ter worth than the mending of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: I smell a pupil. (Aside.) Whence, my Lord, does the young gentleman come?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: You shall hear all about it: You know, Doctor, tho' I'm of a good family distraction—

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Ex.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Tho' I'm of a good family extraction—'twas but t'other day I kept a shop at Gosport.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: The rumour has reached me.—"Fama volat, viresque."

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Don't put me out?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Virgil.—Hem!—Proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: A tradesman, you know, must mind the main chance, so when Dick-began to grow as big as a porpus, I got an old friend of mine, who lives in Derbyshire, close to the Devil's—hum! close to the peak, to take Dick 'pren∣tice, at half price.—He's just now out of his time, and I warrant him, as wild and rough as a rock; now, if you doctor—if you would but take him in hand, and soften him a bit—

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Pray, my Lord—"To soften rocks!" Congreve.—Hem!—Pray, my Lord, what profession may the Honourable Mr. Dowlas have followed?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Who, Dick? He served his clerkship to an attorney, at Castleton,

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: An Attorney!—Gentlemen of his profes∣sion, my Lord, are very difficult to soften.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Yes, but the pay may make it worth the while; I'm told that Lord Spindle gives his eldest son's, master Drumstick's tutorer, three hundred a year; and besides learning his pupil, he has to read my lord to sleep of an afternoon, and walk out with the lap-dogs and chil∣dren. Now, if three hundred a year, doctor, will do the business for Dick, I shan't begrudge it you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Three hundred a-year!—say no more, my Lord. L. L. D. A. double S. and three hundred a-year—I accept the office.—"Verbam Sat." Horace.—Hem!—I'll run to my lodgings—settle with Mrs. Sudds—put my wardrobe into a—No, I've got it all on—and—(going.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Hold! hold! not so hasty, doctor, I must first send you for Dick, to the Blue▪boar?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: The Honourable Mr. Dowlas, my pupil, at the Blue-boar!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Aye, in Holborn, as han't fond of telling people good new before-hand, for fear they may be balk'd; Dick knows nothing of my being made a lord.—

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Three hundred a year—I've often wish'd that I had clear, For life, six—no three,—three hundred.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: I wrote him—just before I left Gosport, to tell him to meet me in London with—

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Three hundred pounds a-year. Swift.—Hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: With all speed, upon business, d'ye mind me?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Doctor Pangloss with an income of—No lap-dogs, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Nay, but listen, Doctor: and as I did'nt know where old Ferrett was to make me live in London, I told Dick to be at the Blue-boar this morning, by the stage-coach—why you don't hear what you are talking about, Doctor?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Oh, perfectly, my Lord.—A Blue-boar in a Stage-coach—with the annuity of—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Well, step into my room, Doctor, and I'll give you a letter which you shall carry to the Inn, and bring Dick away with you. I warrant the boy will be ready to jump out of his skin.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Skin! jump! zounds, I'm ready to jump out of mine. I follow your Lordship.—Oh, Doctor Pangloss, where's your philosophy now?—I attend you, my Lord.—"aequam memento." Horace.—"Servare mentum." Hem! Bless me, I'm all in a fluster!—L. L. D. A. double S. and three hundred a—I attend your Lordship.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter ZEKIEL HOMESPUN, MISS CECILY HOMESPUN, and WAITER.

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: This way, if you please, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: So, here we be at last, in London; a the—What be your sign, young man?

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: The Blue-boar, Sir; the oldest Inn in Holborn.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Oldest! why, as you do say, young man, it do seem in a tumble-downish kind of condition, indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: I'll take care of your portmanteau, if you please? Dinner's on the table, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: (Jirking it from him.) No, but you don't tho'.—I ha' heard o' the tricks o' London, though I ne'er sat foot in it, afore. Master Blue-boar, you ha' gotten the wrong sow by the ear, I can tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Cecily H.
SP.P: La, brother, Zekiel! I dare say, the young man's honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Haply he may be, Cecily! but the honest chaps of this town, as I be told, do need a deal of looking a'ter. Where can Dick Dowlas now be a loitering so long in the yard?

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: The gentleman that came up in the coach with you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Yes, yes; the gentleman wi' all his cloaths in his hand, tied up in a little blue and white pocket-hand∣kerchief.

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Shall I desire him to come up, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Aye, be so kind, will you?

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: I shall, Sir. [Exit Waiter.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: I ha' nothing left but this portmanteau, and you, Cecily: If I was to lose either of you, what would become of poor Zekiel Homespun?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Dear now! this was the cry all along upon the road. Don't be down-hearted. Brother, there be plenty of ways of getting bread in London.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Oh, plenty, plenty;—but many of the ways, they do say, be so foul, and the bread be so dirty, t'would turn a nice stomach, to eat on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Well, I do declare, it seems a pure place! with a power of rich folks, for certain; for I saw No. 945, upon one of their coach-doors, as we came along; and no doubt on't there be more of them still. I do like it, Zekiel!

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Don't ye, now,—dont ye, Cecily, pray don't ye be so merry! You scare me out of my senses—Think what a charge I have of you, Cecily.—Father and mother dead—no kin to help us—both thrown a top o' the wide world, to seek our fortunes, and only I to take care of ye. Indeed, indeed, I do love you, Cecily! you would break your poor brother's heart, if any harm was to befall you. You would'nt do that, would ye, Cecily?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: I, Zekiel! I would'nt hurt a hair of your head, if I was to be made a Lord Mayor's lady, for it. You have been a kind brother to me, Zekiel; and if I have the luck to get a service first, I'd work my fingers to the one to maintain you.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Buss me, Cicely—od rabbit it, girl, I be only chicken hearted on your account.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Well, but let us hope for the best, Zekiel. Poor father has followed mother to the cold grave, sure enough; and the squire out of spite he owed him, has turned us out Castleton farm, but—

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: That were bad enough;—tho' I could ha' stomach'd that—but damn him! (heaven forgive us) he spoke ill o' father's memory. I'd as big a mind to lick 'squire, as ever I had in my life—and then as you say, to turn us adrift!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: But we are young and strong, brother Zekiel, and able to get our living.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Why, that be true enough, Cecily?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Why, then, come now, pluck up a spirit?—be lightsome and jovial a bit, Zekiel—do now?

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Well I—I'll do my best—dang it, if we had but a friend, now.—

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Why, hav'nt we?

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: None that I know of; baiting Dick Dow∣lass, who be come up wi' us, in the Castleton coach.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Well, brother, I sure he'd go thro' fire and water to serve us. He has told me so, Zekiel, fifty good times, the side of old Dobbin's pond, by moonlight.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Aye, I do know he ha' kep' you company, Cecily. I told him, when father died, that I was agreea∣able to his having of you, provided matters got a little smoothish with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Did you? La, Zekiel!

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Dick, be an honest fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: That he is, indeed, brother! (Eagerly.)

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: I ha' known him, now, seven good years, since first he came to Castleton; and we ha' been for all the world, like brothers. Dick be a little rantipolish, but as generous a lad, as—

DIV2.STAGE: Enter DICK DOWLAS, singing to ZEKIEL.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: "Oh, London is a fine town (singing without) a very famous city—(take care of my bundle, d'ye hear)—[Enter]—where all the streets are paved with gold, and all the maidens pretty."—Well, shan't we have a bit of some∣thing to eat?—just a snack, Zekiel, Cis—here, you, Waiter—[Enter Waiter]—What, Cis, my girl—get some cold beef, you—how do'st do, after the journey? Aye, cold beef—put down the bundle—mustard, vinegar, and all that, you know—Cis likes a relish—[puts Dick's bundle on the table, and Exit.]—Aye, jump about, my tight fellow. Zounds! how the rumbling of the old coach keeps whirl∣ing in my head.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: I do think, Dick, your head be always a lit∣tle upon the whirligig order.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: If I hadn't got out to take the reins in hands now and then, I should have been as muzzy as a Methodist parson. Didn't I knock the tits along, nicely, Cis?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Aye, indeed, Dick; except bumping us up against the turn-pike gates, we went as pure and plea∣sant—

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Pshaw! that was an accident. Well, old Domini hasn't called for me here, yet; can't think what the old boy wants with me in London—bad news I'm afraid.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: No, don't you say so; Dick!

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Hap what will, Dick, I'll stand by ye. I be as poor as Job; but I'd share with my friend in misfortune to the last penny.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Tip us your daddle, Zekiel, you've as ten∣der a heart as ever got into the tough carcase of a Castleton farmer—yes, the old boy's last letter but one, told me that things were going on but badly, damn that chandler's shop, bacon, eggs, coals, and candles have laid him low—a bankruptcy I warrant, and come up to town to white-wash.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: And to consult wi' you, may hap, as you be in the lea—about the business.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Gad then, it will be like consulting most peo∣ple in the law, he'll get nothing from me that's satisfactory, old Latitat had as little business as I had inclination in the practice.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Well, but Dick, sure you can do summit in your calling—you can draw up a will, or a lease of a farm, now?

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: I can shoot a wild-duck with any lawyer's clerk in the country, I can fling a bar—play at cricket—

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: That you can: I used to notch for you, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: I can make a bowl of punch—

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: That you can: I used to drink it wi' you you do know.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: I can make love—(To Cis.)

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: That you can, Dick!

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: I can catch gudgeons—

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Aye, aye, that be part of your trade.—Catching o' Gudgeons, be a Lawyer's chiefest employment, they do say.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Well, now to business: here's a newspaper, that I picked up at the bar; there's something in it, I think, that will suit Cis—Read it:

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: (Reading Newspaper). "Wanted a Maid"—

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: That's a difficult thing to be met with in Lon∣don—I take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: So far 'twill do for our Cecily.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Yes—I d better make haste and get the place, for fear any thing should happen, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Le's read it out, Cecily—"Wanted, "a Maid. Servant—by a young lady"—

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Dear, a young Lady!

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: “Who lives very retired at the West end of the town—she must be clean in her person”—Ce∣cily be very clean.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: As any lass in Derbyshire.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: "And good natured."—Cecily be as good∣natured a girl, as ever—Umph!—“and willing to do what is required.”—

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Well, I'm very willing, you know, Dick—a'nt I?

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: That you are, Cis, kiss me. (Kisses her.)

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: La, Dick! This will just do!—I'm so pleased l—

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: "If from the country, the better."—rabbit it, Cecily, this be the very thing!—tol, de rol, lol! “or if any farmer, in difficulties from a numerous family, wishes to put his daughter to a service”—oh, my poor old father! this is the thing! “she will meet with the tenderest care from the lady, who has herself known what it is to be unfortunate.” Tol de rol, lol! buss me, Cecily!—hug me, Dick Dowlass! I shall provide for sister—the care next my very heart.—Tol lol, de rol, lol! Rabbit it! I be ready to choak for joy!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Dear now! This is the rarest luck!—Live with a young lady! I shall be so great and grand—

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: And grow rich with good fortune, and forget your poor friends, Cis.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: No, no, Cecily, be too good for that.—Forget a poor friend! when such giddy folks, chance to get a tumble, they may e'en thank themselves if nobody be ready to help 'em up.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Now, I would'nt have said such words to you Dick, you know, so you do, if I was to be made a queen it would be my pride, Dick, to share all my gold with brother and you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: My dear Cis, well, I'm sorry, faith I am and if ever I or my family should come to fortune—but, pshaw! damn it, my father keeps a chandler's shop without custom.

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: The cloth's laid for you, in the other room, Gentlemen; you can't dine here.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Why so?

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: The Church-wardens come to eat a great din∣ner, once a month, for the good of the poor—this is their day.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: That's as they do down with us.—But I could never find out, why stuffing a churchwarden's guts, was for the good of the poor of the parish.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P:
Nor I neither, unless he got a surfeit that car∣ried him off, come Zekiel, you shall go presently after the place, but first let's refresh, what we eat, will be far the good of the poor, I'm certain.—Cis, your arm,—take
my bundle you dog? and don't drop any thing out, for I've nothing to spare, come Cis.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—Lady CAROLINE DORMER'S House.
DIV3.P: I WISH Kenrick were come back. My last hope hangs upon the answer he will bring me.—World! world!—when afuence points the telescope, how closely does▪ it at∣tract thy venal inhabitants! how magnified are all thy smiles! Let poverty reverse the glass, far distant does it cast them from us, and the features of friendship are dwin∣dled into nothing.—I hear him coming.
Well Kenrick, you have carried the letter?—

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Indeed I have, Miss Caroline.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: And what answer from my father's old friend, Kenrick?

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Faith now your father's old friend, begging your pardon—answered like a big black-guard.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Surely, Kenrick, he could not look surprised at my application?

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Faith, he looked for all the world as if he had swallowed a bottle of vinegar. When I was his honour's (your poor deceased father's) butler, and helped this old friend to good bumpers of madeira, and be-hanged to him; he made clear another sort of a face of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: And has he sent no letter in answer?

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Not a syllable at this present writing, it was all by verbal word of dirty mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Insulting!

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Give my compliments to Miss Caroline Dor∣mer,—says he,—and tell her I'm sorry for her misfortunes: bless you says I,—but I can't be of the smallest service to her: the devil run away with you, think I.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Did he assign no reason?

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Och to be sure, an old skin flint, doesn't he always give you plenty of reasons for being hard-hearted—'tis fitting he should, Miss, because the case requires it, but, compassion is compassion; and that's reason enough for shewing it, in conscience.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: But what said he, Kenrick?

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P:
Her father, Mr. Dormer's, bankruptcy, said he—and a terrible deal of work, too, says I; for you know▪
Miss Caroline, my poor old master, rest his soul, was one of the biggest merchants in the city of London.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: True, Kenrick; but died almost one of its poorest inhabitants.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: That's what the old fellow said: her father has died so involved, says he, that no prudent man can concern himself for the daughter, or run the risque of med∣dling with his affairs—and so he ended with his respects, and a parcel of palaver to you—and an offer of half-a-crown to your humble servant, as an old acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: And yet had my father's prudence been of his complexion. I doubt, Kenrick, whether this man would, now, have had half-a-crown to offer you.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Och, now, if I had but minded to tell him, that—but I made the half-crown tell it him, as plain as it could speak—for I threw it upon the old miser's table, with a great big whack; and by my soul, he never jumped so high at two and six-pence, before, in all his beggarly born days.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Then there is no hope from that quarter, Kenrick?

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: No more hope than there is in a dead coach horse.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: I would wish to be alone, Kenrick: pray leave me.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Leave you! and in grief, Miss Caroline!

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: I wouldn't have you, my good old man, a witness to my affliction.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: What, and was'nt my poor, dear departed wife Judith, your own nurse—wet and dry, for many a a good year; and is'nt myself Felix Kenrick, your own foster father, that have dandled you in these old arms, when you were the size of a dumpling; and will I leave you to take on after this fashion?—alone by yourself. (half crying.)

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Pray, pray, be silent, Kenrick! Oh, na∣ture! spite of the inequalities which birth, or education have placed between thy children—still nature with all thy softness, I own thee! The tear of an old and faithful servant, which bedews the ruins of his shelter, is an honest drop that penetrates the heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Aye, cry away my poor dear Miss Caroline▪ cry away, I shar'd the sunshine of your family, and it is but right that I should go halves in the ruin.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: A poor two hundred pounds, Kenrick, are now all that remain to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P:
Well come; two hundred pounds, now a-days, are not to be sneezed at, consider how consoling it is, m y
dear Miss, to think that with good management, it may be a matter of two years before you are left without a penny in the whole wide world,—and that's four and twenty ca∣lendar months, you know.—

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Had this hollow friend of my father's exerted himself, in the wreck of our house's fortune, he might probably, have averted the penury which threatens me.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Och, if I could but beat humanity into his heart, through his carcase, I'd make him as tender as a sucking pig.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Lord Duberly's death, too, in the moment of my difficulties!—In him I might still have found a protector.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Aye; and his brave son, too, the Hon. Henry Moreland, that was to have married you.—Well, be of good heart, now—for he's dead!—the poor drowned youth!

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Desist, Kenrick, I beseech you!

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Aye, well, now you are unhappy: but you see, I'm after making you happy: Just as the two families had pop'd down, the man of your heart for your husband, faith pop'd himself into the decent watery grave!—I am left the only tender friend you have, to remind you of it—

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Remind me no more, Kenrick, your intention is good; but this is torment to me, instead of—[Zekiel speaks without.] Above stairs? oh, very well, Ma'am—thank you, Ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Croline.
SP.P: Hark! I hear—I hear somebody enquiring for me, on the stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Now, what's the worst of these lodgings, faith people come into your house, before you have opened the door. [A knock at the Door.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Come in?

DIV3.P: have you any business with me friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Why, yes, madam,—it be a smallish bit of business, as a body, may say.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Well, young man?

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Why, yes, ma'am, I become to—pray, if I may make so bold, isn't your name, A. B?

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Oh, I understand, you come in consequence of an advertisement.—I believe you may leave us, Ken∣rick, (exit Kenrick) it was I who advertised for a servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: And with permission, Madam, I be come to offer for the place.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: You, honest friend, as a Maid Servant!

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Yes—for Cecily—Curt'sey, Cecily.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: I do, brother, Zekiel.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: This be my sister, Ma'am—We be newly come from Derbyshire:—and lighting at the Blue-boar—the great Inn, in—Holborn—that—but, perhaps, you may frequent it, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Well, friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Why we stumbled upon your notice in the news, Madam—and so—and so here we be, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Have you ever been in service, before child?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: No, never, if you please, Madam.—I was always with father, and minded the dairy.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: And why did you quit your father, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: He died, if you please, Madam. It was a sad day for brother and I. 'Tis a cruel thing to lose a good father, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: It is, indeed, child. I can well feel it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: And when he dies in distress, too, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Did your father die so, child?

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: All along o' that damned Squire.—Mother ware gone long ago:—and when children be left destitute, it be hard to find a friend to compassionate 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: I—I will be that friend.—My power is little—almost nothing; but as far as it can go, you shall find a protection.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Oh, the gracious!—what a pure lady!

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: But can you refer me to any one for a character?

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: I ha' gotten a character in my pocket, Ma'am. They tell me that be the way they do take most characters in London.—Here be a certificate from Parson Brock, of our parish.▪ (Giving it.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: See, what can you do to be useful, Cecily?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Oh, a power of things;—I can churn and feed the ducks, milk cows, and fatten a pig, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Yes, yes, you will find sister Cecily handy, I warrant her.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: All these will be of little service in London.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Od rabbir it! madam, she will soon learn here, to put her hand to any thing.—Won't you, Cecily?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: If I don't, it shan't be for want of inclina∣tion,—So please you, my lady!

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Well, child, come in the evening, and you shall begin your service. We shall not disagree about wages; and you will be treated more like an humble friend, than a servant. Kenrick!—I shall have only yourself and a poor faithful Irishman.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: An Irishman! dang it, these Irishmen, as I've been told, be devils among the girls, my mind do misgive me; for Cecily be young and thoughtless.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Shew these good people down, Kenrick?

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: I shall do that thing, Miss Caroline.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Oh, then this be the Irishman. He be a plaguy old one, indeed! come, there be nothing to fear about he. A good day to you, Madam.—Curt'sey, Cecily.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Come, you two go first; for I must be after shewing you the way, you know. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: This simple girl's story approachs so near to my own, that it touches me. Poor innocence! mine is a sorry shelter in your wanderings; yet it may be warmer than one more splendid. For—opulence relieves sometimes with coldness, sometimes with oftentation, sometimes with levity: but sympathy kindles the brightest spark that shines on the altar of compassion; and tenderness pours on it the sweetest balm that charity produces, when the afflicted ad∣minister to the afflicted. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Let the chariot turn about.—Doctor Pangloss in a Lord's chariot!—"Curru por-tatur eodem." Juve∣nal.—Hem!—Waiter!

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Have you any gentleman here, who arrived this morning in the Stage?

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: There's one in the house, now, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Is he juvenile?

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: No, Sir; he's Derbyshire.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: He, he, he!—Of what appearance is the gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Why, plaguy poor, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: "I hold him rich, had he not a shirt."—Chau∣cer.—Hem! Denominated the honourable Mr. Dowlas?

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Honourable!—he lest his name plain Dowlas, at the bar, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Plain Dowlas, did he? That will do: "for all the rest is leather"—

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Leather, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: "And Prunello." Pope.—Hem!—Tell Mr. Dowlas a gentleman requests the honour of an interview.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P:
Never before did honour and affluence, let all such a shower on the head of Doctor Pangloss!—Fortune, I thank thee▪—Propitious Goddess, I am grateful!—I, thy ill-favoured child—who commenced his career in the
loftiest apartment of a muffin-maker, in Milk-alley—"lit∣tle did I think, good easy man"—Shakespeare—of the riches and literary dignities which now—(Enter Dick)—my pupil!—

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Well, where is the man that wants—oh, you are he, I suppose—

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: I am the man, young gentleman.—"Homo Sum." Terence.—Hem!—Sir, the person who now pre∣sumes to address you, is Peter Pangloss, to whose name, in the College of Aberdeen, is subjoined L. L. D. signifying Doctor of Laws; to which has been recently added, the distinction of A. double S.—the Roman initials for Fellow of the Society of Arts.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Sir, I'm your most obedient, Richard Dow∣las; to whose name, in his Taylor's bill, is subjoined, D. R. signifying Debtor, to which are added, L. S. D. the Roman initials for Pounds, Shillings, and Pence.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Ha! this youth was doubtless designed by destiny to move in the circles of fashion; for he's dipt in debt, and makes a merit of telling it.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: But what are your commands with me, Doctor?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: I have the honor, young gentleman, of be∣ing deputed as Embassador to you, from your father.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Then you have the honour to be Ambassador of as good-natured an old fellow, as ever sold a halfpenny∣worth of cheese in a chandler's shop.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Pardon me, if on the subject of your father's cheese, I advise you to be as mute as a mouse in one, for the future. 'Twere better to keep that "alta menta re∣postum." Virgil.—Hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Why, what's the matter?—any misfortune? broke, I fear?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: No; not broke; but his name, as 'tis custo∣mary in these cases, has appeared in the Gazette.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Not broke, but Gazetted—why Zounds! and the Devil!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Check your passions—learn philosophy; when the wife of the great Socrates threw a—hum!—threw a tea-pot at his erudite head, he was as cool as a cucumber.—When Plato—

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Damn Plato!—what of my father?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Don't damn Plato—the bees swarmed round his mellifluous mouth, as soon as he was swaddled. "Cum in cunis apes in labellis consedissent." Cicero.—Hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: I wish you had a swarm round your's, with all my heart—come to the point.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: In due time. But calm your choler.—"Ira furor brevis est." Horace.—Hem!—[Gives a letter.]

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: [Snatches it and breaks it open]—“Dear Dick, this comes to inform you, I am in a perfect state of health, hoping you are the same”—Aye, that's the old beginning—"it was my lot, last week, to be made"—a bankrupt, I suppose—to be made a—what?—to be made "a PEAR!"—a pear—to be made a pear!—what the devil does he mean by that?—

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: A peer—a Peer of the realm.—His Lord∣ship's orthography is a little loose, but several of his equals countenance the custom. Lord Loggerhead always spells Physician with an F.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: [Reads on.] "A Peer!"—what, my father? I am electrified—old Daniel Dowlas made a Peer of the Realm?—"Lawyer Ferroll got me my tittle"—tittle—Oh, title;—“and an estate of Fifteen Thousand per an∣num; whereby making me out next a-kin to old Lord Duberly, because he died without hair.”—'Tis an odd reason, by the bye, to be next a-kin to a nobleman because he died bald!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: His Lordship means heir. We shall melio∣rate his style speedily. "Reform it altogether." Shake∣speare.—Hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: "I send my carrot." Carrot!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: He, he, he! Chariot his Lordship means.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: "With Doctor Pangloss in it."

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: That's me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: "Respect him; for he's an L. L. D. and moreover an A. double S." Both bows.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: His Lordship kindly condescended to insert that, at my request.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.Q: “And I have made him your tutorer, to mend your cakelology.”

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Cacology:—from Kakos malus and Logos ver∣bum.—vide Lexicon.—Hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Dick. D.
SP.P: "Come with the Doctor to my house, in Hanover-square."—Hanover-square!—“”I remain your af∣fectionate father to command,

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: That's his Lordship's title.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: It is!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: It is.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Say Sir, to a Lord's son. You have no more manners than a Bear.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Bear! under favour, young gentleman, I am the bear-leader; being appointed your Tutor.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick. D.
SP.P: And what can you teach me?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Prudence—don't forget yourself in sudden success. "Tecum habita." Persais.—Hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Prudence to a Nobleman's son, with fifteen thousand a year.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Don't give way to your passions.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick. D.
SP.P: Give way—Zounds! I'm wild—mad—you teach me—pooh—I've been in London before, and know it requires no teaching to be a modern fine gentleman—why it all lies in a nutshell:—Sport a curricle—walk Bond-street—play at Faro—get drunk—dance reels—go to the Opera—cut off your tail—pull on your pantaloons—and there's a buck of the first fashion in town for you—Damme! d'ye think I don't know what's going?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Mercy on me! I shall have a very refractory pupil!

SP.SPEAKER: Dick. D.
SP.P: Not at all; we'll be hand and glove together. My little Doctor, I'll drive you down to all the races, with my terrier between your legs, in a tandem.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Doctor Pangloss, the philosopher, with a terrier between his legs in a tandem.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: I'll tell you what, Doctor—I'll make you my long stop, at cricket—you shall draw corks, when I'm pre∣sident—laugh at my joke before company—squeeze lemons for punch—cast up the reckoning—and woe betide you, if you don't keep sober enough to see me safe home after a jollification.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Make me a long stop, and a squeezer of le∣mons!—Zounds! this is more fatiguing than walking out with the lap dogs! and are these the qualifications for a Tutor, young gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Dick. D.
SP.P: To be sure, they are. It's the way that half the prig parsons, who educate us Honourables, jump into sat livings.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: 'Tis well they jump into something fat at last, for they must wear all the flesh off their bones in the process.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick. D.
SP.P: Come, now, tutor, go you, and call the waiter?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Go, and call!—Sir, Sir!—I'd have you to understand, Mr. Dowlas—

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Aye, let us understand one another, doctor, my father, I take it, comes down handsomely to you, for your management of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: My Lord has been liberal.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: But, 'tis I must manage you, doctor, ac∣knowledge this, and between ourselves, I'll find means to double your pay.—

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Double my—

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Do you hesitate—why, man, you have set up for a modern tutor, without knowing your trade?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Double my pay!—say no more—Done.—"actum est." Terence.—'Gad I've reached the right read∣ing at last—
"I've often wish'd that I had clear,
"For life, six hundred pounds a year."—Swift.—Hem!—Waiter!

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: That's right, tell him to pop my cloaths and linen into the carriage, they are in that bundle?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Here, put all the Honourable Mr. Dowlas's cloaths and linen into his father's, Lord Duberly's, chariot.

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: All,—where are they, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: All wrapt up in the Honourable Mr. Dow∣las's pocket-handkerchief.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: See them safe in, doctor, and I'll be with you presently?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: I go, most worthy pupil. Six hundred pounds a year! However deficient in the classics, his knowledge of arithmetick is admirable!—I've often wish'd that I had clear, for life—

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Nay, nay, don't be so slow?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Swift.—Hem!—I'm gone. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: What am I to do with Zekiel and Cis?—When a poor man is grown great, his old acquaintance ge∣nerally begins to be troublesome.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Well, I ha'nt been long.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: No, you are come time enough in all conscience.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Cecily ha' gotten the place. I be almost stark wild with joy. Such a good-natured young Madam!—why you don't seem pleased, man, sure, and sure you be glad of our good fortune, Dick.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Why, what do you? Oh, but he don't know yet, that I am a Lord's son. I rejoice to hear of your success, friend Zekiel.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Why now, that's hearty.—But eh?—Why you look mortal heavy and lumpish, Dick; no bad tidings since we ha' been out, I hope?

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Oh, no!

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Eh?—Let's ha' a squint at you. Od rabbit, but something ha' happened. You ha' seen your father, and things ha' gone crossih—Who have been here, Dick?

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Only a gentleman, who had the honour of being reputed Embassador from my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: What a dickens, an Embassador!—Pish, now you be a queering a bodyt An Embassador sent from an old Chandler to Dick Dowlas, lawyer Latitat's clerk!—come, that be a good one, fegs!

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Dick Dowlas! and Lawyer's Clerk!—Sir, the gentleman came to inform me, that my father by being proved next of kin to the late Lord—is now Lord Duber∣ly; by which means I'm the Hon. Mr. Dowlas.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Odds flesh, gi' us your fist, Dick!—I ne'er shook the fist of an honourable afore, in all my born days. Old Daniel made a lord! I be main glad to hear it,—this be news indeed! but Dick, I hope he ha' gotten some ready along wi' his title.—For a lord without money be but a foolish, wishy washy kind of a thing a'ter all.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: My father's estate is 15,000l. a year.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Mercy on us! you ha' an away my breath!

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Well, Zekiel, Cis and you shall hear from me soon.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Why you be'nt a going Dick?

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: I must pay my duty to his Lordship—his cha∣riot waits for me, below. We have been some-time ac∣quainted, Zekiel, and you may depend on my good offices.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: You do seem a little frustrated wi' these tidings, Dick.—I should be loth to think our kindness was a cooling.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Oh, no! rely upon my protection.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Why, look ye, Dick Dowlas; as to pro∣tection, and all that, we ha' been old friends, and if I should need it from you, it be no more nor my right to expect it, and your business to give it me. But Cecily ha' gotten a place, and I ha' hands and health to get a live∣lihood. Fortune, good, or bad, tries the man, they say—and if I should hap to be made a Lord to-morrow (as who can say what may betide, since they ha' made one of an old Chandler)—

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Well sir, and what then?

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Why then, the finest feather in my lordship's cap, would be to shew there be as much shame in slighting an old friend, because he be poor, as there be pleasure in owning him, when it be out of our power to do him a service.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: You mistake me, Zekiel—I—I—'sdeath—I'm quite confounded. I'm trying to be as fashionable as my neighbous; but nature comes in, and knocks it all in the head. Zekiel, give me your hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Then there be a hearty Castleton slap for you. The grasp of an honest man can't disgrace the hand of a Duke, Dick.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P:
You're a kind soul. Zekiel, I regard you sincerely—I love Cecily, and—damn it, I'm going too far now, for a Lord's son. Pride and old friendship are fight∣ing
in me, 'till I'm almost bewildered—you shall hear from me, in a few hours. Good bye, Zekiel; good bye. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: I don't know what ails me, but I be almost ready to cry.—Dick be a high-mettled youth, and this news ha' put him a little beside himself. I should make a bit of allowance. His heart, I do think, be in the right road, and when that be the case, he be a hard judge, that won't pardon an old friends spirits, when they do carry him a little way out on't [Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—A Chamber in an Inn.

SP.SPEAKER: WAITER.
SP.P: THIS way, gentlemen, if you please, this is our best apartment,—our hotel provides dinners.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: No chattering?—We have business.—Wel∣come, at last, Mr. Moreland, to London. After wander∣ing over foreign lands, with what joy an Englishman sets his foot on British ground! His heart swells with pleasure as he drives through his fat native soil, which ruddy labour has cultivated; 'till he reaches this grand reservoir of opu∣lence, an opulence which may well make him proud, for its honourable source is his countrymen's industry.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: To you, Stedfast; who have no private fears, no anxieties for your family, the satisfaction must be exquisite.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Why, I'm an old batchelor, 'tis true—and without relations; but the whole country is my family.—I could not help thinking, as we posted to town, that every jolly peasant, and every cherry cheek'd lass, was a kind of humble brother and sister to me; and they called forth my affections accordingly. Rich or poor, great or small, we all form one chain Henry: May the larger and lesser links hold kindly together, 'till time slides into eternity.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: A truce to these reflections now, my dear Stedfast.—They do your heart honour, but mine is filled with a thousand apprehenions—my father!—my Caroline!—

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: A father and a mistress! duty and love, that's a slow fire, and a fierce blazc; and doubt blowing the bellows upon 'em. 'Tis enough to scorch a young soul to a cinder,

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P:
'Tis strange I never heard from either of them. After escaping the perils of shipwreck! After the suffer∣ings' that followed—a father, a mistress, soon to be made
a wife, might surely have sent one line to testify their pleasure at my preservation.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Aye, now make yourself miserable, a young mind is too soon sanguine, and therefore too soon depressed.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Why what can be the reason they have never answered my letters?

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Um! there is one reason, indeed, that—

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: You alarm me!—What can that be?

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: That they have never received them.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Impossible!

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Nothing more likely; consider, your last let∣ter from Quebec, told your father, Lord Duberly, that you had avenged all the business which had call'd you there, and that in three days you should embark for England.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Well, that he never answered.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: I can't tell—probably not. Most people think it somewhat superfluous to write to a correspondent at Quebec, after he has left the place.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Pshaw! I'm bewildered.—But since—

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Why since, the chances have been against you.—Wreck'd on our passage—thrown upon the uninha∣bited part of the island of Cape Breton—

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: I shall never think of it without horror, nor without gratitude, Stedfast. To your friendly care, stran∣gers as we then were to each other, in that frozen shore of desolation, I owe my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Pshaw!—nonsense—We both met as fellow∣passengers, and were fellow-sufferers; I happened to be the toughest, that's all.—I do as we would be done by, is merely a part of our duty!—But, there's so much fuss about it, now, that, I'm afraid the duty is too often ne∣glected.—I suppose we shall soon thank our shoe-black for brushing our boots, though we reward him for the business.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Yet humanity, Stedfast—

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Is every man's business, and the reward he will ultimately receive for it as far above human calcula∣tion. But come, thank providence, and not me.—To furvive at the end of two months, when most of the small parcel of our comrades were dead, or dying about us, with cold and hunger, is no common escape.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: And then in a desperate hope to launch our shat∣tered boat in quest of an inhabited country, and to be tossed about for two months more, 'till benumbed and pe∣rishing, we were discovered by the natives and friendly Indians.—All this, Stedfast, was indeed a stout trial.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P:
Then away with rifling fears, now, since our deliverance, we have changed our ground, daily, on our
turn to England, the time—the distance—your letters—theirs—all may have miscarried.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: May it prove so. But let me hasten to my fa∣ther's and clear my doubts.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Stay, stay, stay. You know 'twas at my request you drove to this hotel; now pray, at my request let me wait on Lord Duberly, to prepare him for your ap∣pearance.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: For what purpose?

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: A very evident one. The wreck of our ship, has doubtless, long been public in London. And as the cew and passengers are probably all supposed to have pe∣rished, your abrupt entrance at your father's, might be too much for him.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: You are perfectly right. In the moment when our passions are afloat, how beneficial is the cool advice of a friend to direct us. But shouldn't I give you a line of introduction to my father?

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Umph! why according to usual form, indeed—but I was never good at forms; and, in this case, it may be better to let me introduce myself in my own way. I hope Lord Duberly is no stickler for ceremonies.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: He has the manliest virtue and the warmest heart in the world, my friend, but I confess to those who are unacquainted with them, these qualities are a little con∣cealed by a coldness in his manner that—

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Oh, I understand.—A little stately or so.—

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Only a little of the veille coeur about him. A long habit too, of haranguing in Parliament, gives a man a kind of dignity of deportment, and an elevation of style not to be met with every day you know. But Gentle∣man is written legibly upon his brow; erudition shines thro' every polished period of his language; and he is the best of men, and of fathers, believe me.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Aye, aye. I see—I see.—Grand and stiff, ut of sterling value, like an old fashion'd silver candle∣stick.—Well, I'll soon bring you an account of my em∣bassy.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: And while you are at my father's, I'll walk to Mrs. Dormer's; my suspense about Caroline is intolerable. I must see the good old gentleman, and he will break my arrival to his daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Meet me, then, here, in a couple of hours.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Be it so, a thousand thanks my dear Stedfast.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P:
A thousand fiddlestick! I hae to be thank'd a thousand times for a trifle.—I know 'tis the language of the day; but modern complimentary cant is the coin∣age of dishonesty, for the profession exceeds the feeling;
—and nine men in ten who give it under their hands, that they are your devoted humble servants, pledge them∣selves to you for much more than they ever mean to per∣form. [Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—Lord DUBERLY'S House.
DIV3.STAGE: Lady DUBERLY discovered with DOCTOR PANGLOSS.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: And how does my Lord come on in his learn∣ing, Doctor?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Apt—very apt, indeed, for his age.—Defec∣tive in nothing, now, but words, phrases and grammar.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: I wish you could learn him to follow my ex∣ample, and be a little genteel:—but there's no making a silk purse out of a sow's ear, they say.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Time may do much. But, as to my Lord, every body has'nt your Ladyship's exquisite elegance.—"Upon my soul a lie." Shakespeare—Hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: A mighty pretty spoken man!—and you are made tutorer, I'm told, Doctor, to my Dicky?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: That honour has accrued to your obsequious servant, Peter Pangloss: I have now the felicity of super∣intending your Ladyship's Dicky.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: I mustn't have my son thwarted, Doctor—for when he has his way in every thing, he's the sweetest tempered youth in Christendom.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: An extraordinary instance of mildness!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Oh, as mild as mother's milk, I assure you.—And what is he to learn, doctor?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pan.
SP.P: Our readings will be various—Logic, Ethics, and Mathematics; History, Foreign and Domestic; Geo∣graphy, Ancient and Modern; Voyages and Travels, An∣tiquities, British and Foreign, Natural History, Natural and moral philosophy, Classics, Arts, and Sciences, Belles Lettres, and Miscellanies.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Bless me! 'tis enough to batter the poor boy's brains to a mummy.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: "A little learning"

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Little!—a load!—

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: "Is a dangerous thing" Pope.—Hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: And you have left out the main article.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: What may your Ladyship mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Mean!—Why dancing to be sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Doctor Pangloss, the philosopher, teach to dance!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P:
Between whiles you might give Dick a les∣son or two in the hall—as my lord's valet plays on the
kit, it will be quite handy to have you both in the house, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: This is a damned barbarous old woman! With submission to your Ladyship, my business is with the the head, not with the heels, of my pupil.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Fiddle faddle! Lady Betty tells me, that the heads of young men of fashion, now a-days, are by no means overloaded. They are left to the Barber and Dentist.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: 'Twould be daring to dispute so self-evident an axiom—But if your Ladyship—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Look ye doctor,—he must learn to dance and jabber French, and I would'nt give a brass farden for any thing else—I know what's elegance, and you'll find the gray mare the better horse, in this house, I promise you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Her Ladyship, I perceive, is paramount.—"Puz femmina facti" Virgil.—Hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: What's your pay here, Mr. tutorer?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Three hundred per annum—that is—no, three—no—aye, no matter:—the rest's between me and Mr. Dowlas. (Aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Do as I direct you, in private, and, to pre∣vent words, I'll double it.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Double it! What, again!—nine hundred per ann! I'll take it!—"Your hand, a Covenant." Shakespeare.—Hem! Zounds! I've got beyond the read∣ing at last!—"I've often wish'd that I had clear for life"—I hear my Lord—"Nine hundred pounds a year? Swift.—Hem!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter LORD DUBERLY and DICK DOWLAS.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Come along, Dick, here he is again my lady, Twist, the Taylor, happened to come in promiscoussy, as I may say, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Accidentally, my Lord, would be better.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Aye, accidentally—with a suit of my Lord Docktail's under his arm—and as we were in a bit of a rumpus, to rig-out Dick, why—

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Dress.—not rig—unless metaphorically.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Well,—dress out,—why we—humph! Dr. don't brother. In short we popt Dick into them,—and Twist says they hit to a hair.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Yes; they are quite the dandy; ar'nt they, mother?—This is all the go, now, they say—cut straight—that's the thing—square waist—wrap over the knee, and all that—slouch is the word now!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Exceedingly genteel, I declare! Turn about, Dick; they don't pinch you, do they?

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Oh, no! just as if I had been measured.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Pinch! lord love you, my lady, they set like a sack.—But why don't you stand up? the boy rolls about like a porpus in a storm.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: The very air and grace of our young no∣bility!

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: That's the fashion father—that's modern ease young Oats, the beau brewer, from the boro', brought it down, last Christmas, to Castleton. A young fellow is nothing now without the Bond-street roll, a tooth-pick be∣tween his teeth, and his knuckles crammed into his coat-pockets—then away you go, lounging lazily along—Oh, Tom—what Will! Rolling away, you see—How are you, Jack?—What, my little Dolly!—That's the way—Isn't it, mother?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Is it? Grace must have got plaguy limber, then, and lopt of late.—There's the last lord Duberly's father done in our dining room, with a wig as wide as a wash-tub, and stuck up as stiff as a poker. He was one of your tip-tops, too, in his time, they tell me:—he car∣ried a gold stick before George the first.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Yes; and looks for all the world as straight as if he swallowed it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: No matter for that, my lady;—what signi∣fies dignity without it's crakeristick—a man should know how to bemean himself, when he is as rich as Pluto.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Plutus, if you please, my Lord.—Pluto, no doubt, has disciples and followers of fashion; “But Plu∣tus is the ruler of riches.” Hessiod.—Hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: There Dick, d'ye hear how the tutorer talks? oh rabbit it! he can ladle you out of Latin by the quart;—and grunts greek like a pig. I've gin three hundred a year, and settled all he's to learn you.—Han't I, doctor?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Certainly my lord, "thrice to thine?

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Yes; we know all about that—don't we, Doctor?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Decidedly, "and thrice to thine?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Aye, aye, clearly understood—isn't it, Doc∣tor?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Undoubtedly, “”and thrice again to make up nine? Sheakspeare—Hem!

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: My Lord, there's a Mr. Stedfast below, wants to speak to you below about particular business.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Muster Stedfast! never heard of the name, curse me, my lad;—tell him I'll be with him in the twinkling of a bed-post.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Yes, my Lord. [Exit John.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: I shall go with your Lordship through the gallery, for I must dress to attend Lady Betty.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Come along, then my lady.—Dick go with the tutorer—he'll give you a lesson in my library—plenty of learning there! I promise you. I was looking at it all of a row, this here very morning.—There's all Horace's Operas, doctor, and such a sight of French Books! but I see by the books they are all written by Tom.—Come along my Lady? [Exit with Lady Duberly.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: On what subject, Mr. Dowlass, shall we commence on researches, this evening?

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: I mean to light up the billiard-room—we'll knock about the balls a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Knock about the balls!—an admirable en∣trance upon a course of studies!—

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Do you know any thing of the game?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: I know how to pocket, young gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: So do most tutors, Doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: If I could but persuade you to peep into a classic.—

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Peep—why, you prig of a fellow, don't I pay you because I won't peep?—Talk of this again, and I'm off in our contract.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Are you? I'm dumb.—"Mammon leads me on." Milton.—Hem! I follow. [Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: A noble house, faith! and bespeaks some of that stately dignity in the owner; which my friend Harry hinted to me.—His lordship, I warrant, is as stiff as backram—with a pompous display of language that puz∣zles a plain man to keep with him.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Sir, his Lordship said he'd be with you in the twinkling of a bed-post. [Exit John.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Zounds! that's the oddest phrase for a fine spoken peer, I ever met with.—The ignorance of the servant, I suppose. These blockheads never know how to deliver a message. Oh here he comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Sir, you are kindly wel∣come.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Kindly welcome! condescending at least; but not quite so dignified as I expected.—(aside) I am a rough traveller, my Lord, ungifted with you flow of dic∣tion, and having real business, I trust that without further preface, it may plead my apology.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Aye, aye, business is business; and words, you know butter no parsnips—

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Butter no parsnips!—why he's sneering at my plainness;—or I have mistaken the person; I have the ho∣nor, I think, of addressing Lord Duberly?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: To be sure you have, as sure as eggs is eggs. Come, muster—mayhap you may chuse a morsel of summat?

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Not any thing, I—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Don't say so. A drop of wine, now; or a sneaker of punch—or—

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Nothing, my Lord.—I am thunderstruck!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Well, now then for the piece of business?

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: I have had some fears, my Lord, that I might be too abrupt in the disclosure; but, since this introduc∣tion.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Oh, rot it! I was never for no long rigma∣role, not I! an honest man's meaning, needs no flourishes. Honesty's like a good piece of roast beef, Muster Stedfast, it lacks little garnish, and the more plainer, the more pa∣latable.—That's my sentiment.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: I admire your sentiment, my Lord;—but I can't say much for your language. (aside)—I must inform your lordship, that no great length of time has elapsed since I—don't be agitated—left Quebec, in America.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: A Yankee doodle, may-hap?

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: A Yankee doo!—I am no Ameri∣can, my lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: No offence to you,—but seeing you have got a tawneyish tinge, (rises.) I thought you might be a little out-landish.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: I shall ever be proud in being able to say that I am an Englishman; but should suppose recently arrived from the country I have named, must interest your feelings.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Interest—why what's he at? if I seem not to understand, now, I shall make some pleaguy hole in my manners, I warrant (aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: I perceive by your silence, that your lordship, is affected. A person in your situation cannot naturally be otherwise.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Then it's the fashion, for a peer to be in a pucker, when any body comes from Quebec in America. (aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Pray inform me, my Lord, have you received any letter from your on, since he wrote to advise you, he had finished the business which induced you to send him from home, and, that, he was immediately preparing to meet you in London?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Since that? no, to be sure.—Why, lord love you, he set out directly after it, on purpose to come.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: And your lordship has heard no news from any of his fellow passengers?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Fellow passengers!—no, not I—neither in∣side nor out.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Inside nor out! It's plain, however, that we are all supposed to have gone to the bottom. (Aside) Know then, my Lord, I was his fellow-passenger.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Was you? You are just come up then, it seems.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Come up! This is an easy way of talking to a man supposed to be drowned. (aside). I am here, you see, my Lord: but Providence be praised, it was never my fate to go down.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Well, well, that's no matter of mine. Your fate may have lain another way, to be sure, as you say.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Another way!—Zounds! he can't dare to in∣sinuate, that I was born to be hanged! (Aside.) He ap∣pears the most ignorant, unfeeling—Hear me, my Lord. Has your son ever been dear to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Plaguy dear, indeed, muster Stedfast; only ax Doctor Pangloss.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: An intimate, I suppose, to whom your Lord∣ship has unburthened your mind, in private?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Yes, he mends my cakelology every morning, and is moreover a great philosopher.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: On such an occasion, a father might well call in philosophy to his assistance.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: I hired him a purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Hired him!—Hired a philosopher to console him for the death of his son!—Delicacy, is superfluous here, I see.—In short, my Lord, I come to inform you, your son, lost as he has been to the world, has newly and unexpectedly entered into life.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Well; and what then?

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: What then! The brutal apathy in this post of a Peer, makes me ready to beat him. (Aside. Why then, he has this day arrived in town; here, in this metropolis.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Why, what signifies a cock and a bull story, about what I know already.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Know it!—It must be by inspiration, then. By what supernatural sign have you discovered his arrival?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: What sign?—Why a Blue-boar.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P:
My Lord, my Lord,—ignorance—little, indeed, from the account I received from a blindly affec∣tionate youth, did I expect to find it here. Ignorance may palliate meanness and buffoonery, and merely meet contempt, but want of feeling excites indignation. You
have shocked me, and I leave you. From exalted rank like yours, my Lord, men lock for exalted virtue; and when these are coupled, they command respect, and grace each other:—but the coronet, which gives and receives splendour, when fixed on the brow of merit, glitters on the worthless head, like a mark of disgrace, to render vice, folly, and inhumanity conspicuous. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: That there chap's mad!—he has put me all of a twitter. If my Lady had happened to be here, I'm sure she would have paspired with fear.—John!

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: My Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Has the porter let out that there man?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Yes, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Never let him clap his damned ugly mug in these here dors again. He is as mad as any poor soul un∣der a statue of lunacy. Shut the door, d'ye hear.—Od rabbit it! if Pers are to be frightened in this here fashion, I'd rather serve soap and candles again in comfort at Gos∣port. [Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.—Enter DICK DOWLAS and ZEKIEL HOME∣SPUN.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Well, but at this unseasonable time of—

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: I couldn't help it, Dick.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Isn't the fashion to pay a visit at this time of the evening—who let you in?

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Why a fat man in the hall, that pop't out of a leather chair, that comes all over his head like a tub.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: The porter, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Belike it was. He has tassels a▪ top of his shoulders, and a sight of binding, that looks like parsly and butter, about his waistcoat.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: But why did you come now:

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Why I do tell you, I was uneasy about ye, Dick, I couldn't ha' staid away, if I was to be hanged for't.—You did promise to meet us, this afternoon.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: I have been prevented; we young fellows of fashion can't answer for our hours.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Ah, Dick, London fashions and friendship, I do fear, go seldom cheek by jowl. I ha' just left Cecily at the place.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Well, and what of her, Zekiel?

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Poor soul! she ha' been sobbing, ready to burst her heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Cecily in tears!—for what?

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: All along o' you man. You did promise to come, and she do tell me, she never know'd you to break your word till you were made a gentleman. I said all I could to comfort her.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: And what did you say, Zekiel?

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Why I told her, that you had always dealt fair and open with her, 'till now—and if you could be honest to her when you were a lawyer, there might be some hope of your being so now, even though you be an ho∣nourable.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Well, well; I shall see her to-morrow, and see you too, Zekiel; and settle some plan for her; and—

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Plan?—why the plan be settled already—and, you do know, she be in place, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Pshaw!—in place will never do; I have a liking for her, you know; and when—

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: A liking!

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Yes; that's a love, you know; and a regard for you, Zekiel—and, in short, a girl on whom Lord Duberly's son has fixed his affections, must not remain in service; it would disgrace one of us.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: It can't disgrace one of us, Dick.—A good girl who have lost her parents support, and do get her bread in honest industry, be a pride instead of a disgrace, to any one that loves her, you do know.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: I didn't mean that; I—

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Noa—noa—bless you, 'tware only your good heart run away wi' you. You do wish us well, Dick—you do wish to serve us; and overshot yourself a little, i what you said, that be all.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Why, look ye, Zekiel; you are a well-mean∣ing lad—

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Aye, and so be you, Dick; I ware getting a bit tiffish wi' you at the Blue-boar. I did think sudden pride ware going to turn you topsy-turvey—I was angry at myself, afterwards.—But I do beg your pardon—heartily, my good friend—faith heartily.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Nay; hear me: 'tis fit we should understand one another—which we don't seem to do—at present.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Don't us! Ecod I should be grieved at that, Dick.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Listen to me. My situation, you see, is much altered.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Woundedly indeed!—Here be a house—and what a brave coat you ha' gotten on, Dick.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P:
No matter; but there are situations in the world, Zekiel, that do not always tally: chance may re∣move one man so far from another, in the rank of life; that,
tho' their good-will may continue, the same custom requires, that they should not live exactly—mind, I say, not exactly, on the same footing.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: I see what you be driving at, Dick; I see it; I did fear it, all along. Well, well, —I do know that I be'nt fit company for a Lord's son;—but when a Lord was once a Chandler, I thought indeed—no matter—bless thee, Dick.—I shall always wish thee well!

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Nay, nay; I dont mean that we should separ∣ate; on the contrary, I wish we may be closer in friend∣ship than ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Ah, Dick! I ha' loved thee!—I'd ha' parted wi' my last farthing to—no matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
