SP.P: There is no occasion to take it in this manner; we may be both rich, both happy, Zekiel: But, you know, how impossible it is for the son of a Peer to marry your sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Ay, aye, I do see it—it be all over.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: No reason for that on earth; for though the world places a distance between Cis and me, as to matri∣mony; yet it makes an allowance for every thing else.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: I don't understand you, Dick.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: My rank not permitting the usual forms be∣tween us, which my regard for her happiness makes me wish, could take place; all I can now do is to raise her from future fear of poverty; and we may be man and wife in every thing but the ceremony.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Oh, now I do understand ye.—You be a rascal!—Odds flesh! I shall choak!—a damed rascal—keep out o' my way or I may do ye a mischief.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Nay, but—

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Dick, Dick!—Had a stranger done this, I'd ha' knocked him down: but a dear friend, to turn traitor—(bursts into tears.)—Damme, it's too▪ much,—I▪ can't stand it!

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Well; but only hear me—

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: I ha' heard too much, already—(To Dick.) Rot it! I be ashamed to be such a blubberer!—But the greatest shame do light upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: I begin to feel that it does, Zekiel.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: And well you may. If it be the part of a Lord's son to stab his friend to the heart, by robbing his sister of her honesty, much good may do ye, wi' your grandeur.—But let me tell your grandeur this, Mr. Dow∣las; you do know some'at (little enow to be sure) of the laa; and the laa of the land do make no difference between a Peer and a Ploughman—if you do dare to hurt Cecily, the laa shall lay you flat, in the first place, and my plough∣man's fist, in the second!—and so my service to you. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: My heart upbraids me. I have wounded, at one blow, an honest man, and an innocent girl, whom reason and inclination tell me to love. Now, am I so mere a beginner, that whether this is, or is not fashionable, curse me, if I know; but I have been told it is. I must go deeper into its mysteries, or abstain from it altogether; and, I feel so much pain already, that in this same career of fashion, where feeling they say is banished, I shall make a very aukward figure. [Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—Lady CAROLINE DORMER'S House.
DIV3.STAGE: Cecily discovered seated, crying, and leaning on Zekiel.

SP.SPEAKER: ZEKIEL.
SP.P: DO you, do ye cheer up a bit, sister Cecily! don't ye take on so—don't ye, now!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: O, Zekiel! for certain my poor heart will break.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Don't ye, say so, Cecily, for that would go nigh to break mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: I never will give ear to a lawyer's vows as long us I do breathe.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Aye, that be what all the girls say over and over.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: A base perjury man!

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: That he be!—he ha' stung me to the quick.—a Viper!—and offer to abuse you—damn him!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Oh, don't you say that of him, Zekiel, I can't bear that, tho' he has been so cruel to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Then pluck up a bit of spirit, now.—Pray ye do. You ha' gotten a good place you do know, and things will go well enow, I warrant us. How dos't like madam, eh, Cecily!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Purely! she is so tender and kind to me, Ze∣kiel—Heigho!

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Come, dry your tears, now, Cecily. I would be main glad to find madam be so kind to you. What did ye do, a'ter I left you last?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Why I was but poorly, Zekiel.—I had been crying you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel▪ H.
SP.P: Yes, yes, but don't ye cry any more, Cecily.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: And when madam Caroline saw it, she was so kind, and so comfortable to me!

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Was she?—good soul!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: And she bid me go to rest—and spoke as sweet, and took as much care of me, as poor mother used to do.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Bless her for it, if I be ever able to make a return, I'll—

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Dear, I hear her in next room! she is up! and if she should catch us here. There now.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Cecily, child! I thought you had'nt risen.—I did'nt wish you to attend if you were unwell, my poor girl!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Thank you, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Thank you very kindly, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Oh, your brother, I see.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: At your humble service, madam. I made bold to call to see how sister were, and to make my humble duty to you, madam. Cecily do tell me you ha' been main kind to her.—We be poor, madam, but I do hope you will be pleased to take our thanks, without offence.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Offence! honest friend!—to merit and receive the thanks of the poor, is one of the heart's best gratifications.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: She be main good-natured, indeed! I—I had a little bit of a favour to ask, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: What is it, friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Why here be a scrap of paper here—it were poor father's—if you would be pleased to tell me if it be worth any thing, now it be so old.—(gives a Lottery Ticket.)

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: It is worth enquiring after.—'Tis an old Lot∣tery Ticket. (returning it.)

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Psha! then it be of little good.—Father had no luck that way—but, for all mother could say, he was always a dabbling, and a dabbling. I'll see about it, at shop, tho'—I do wish you a dutiful good morning, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: A good day, friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: (apart to Cecily.) Pluck a spirit, do ye now, Cecily. Gi' me a buss—there, now, let that comfort ye, a bit.—I'll call and bye.—A good day to you, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: You do not look recover'd yet, Cecily.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: I shall be better in time, if you please, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Come, child—you musn't give way to low spirits. Your situation is new to you, indeed, but this fickle world is full of changes, Cecily.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: (crying) Oh, dear me! sure enough this world is full of fickleness and change!

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Well, but do not cry thus, child!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: I must cry, if you please, madam, I can't help it, indeed, I can't.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Poor girl! does any thing press heavy on your mind?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Yes, yes, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: What is it? is it in my ability to relieve you?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Oh, no, madam.—It's quite out of your power to give me what I have lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Lost, child! have you lost any thing since you came to London?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Yes, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Any thing you brought up in the coach with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Yes, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Your cloaths? or a parcel? or—

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: No, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: What then, child?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: A young man, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Lost a young man, Cecily!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: He was once the truest hearted youth! Law∣yer Lattitat's clerk, of our town, if you please, madam—we were to be married—Brother was agreeable to it; and now he has basely left me, and all because he grown rich and great.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: What, since last night! That is somewhat sudden, indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Aye, I should as soon look'd to have been, as to think my Dick would be made a lord's son.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Made a lord's son! how, Cecily?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: I don't know how they make lords sons, madam—but his father has had a good fortune, by a death, and so Dick is now son to Lord Duberly.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Lord Duberly, good heavens! how that name agitates me! the present Lord Duberly, you mean, Cecily.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Yes, if you please, madam, the last lord—Zekiel heard all from the porter—the last lord's son was drowned at sea, they say—perhaps you may have heard on't, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: I have—I have indeed, Cecily?—(agitated.)

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Oh dear! an't you well, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Yes, I—I—'s nothing, Cecily,—and so your lover, poor wench, has deserted you?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Oh, worse than that, madam, brother is al∣most out of his wis about it,—for he said, a base cruel man!—He would make my fortune by ruinating me.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Poor simplicity! dry your tears my good girl; and rather rejoice that you have escaped the snares of a profligate, you shall not want protection while I can give it you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Heaven bless you! you are very kind, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Och, murther, murther, your very kind, ma∣dam, Miss Caroline.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Well Kenrick?

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Och, why did'nt I die before I was born, to see this ill looking day.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Why, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: The matter' and hav'nt I trotted into Lom∣bard-street, to get your draught turned into money.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: To be sure—for there lies the little which I now possess, Kenrick.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Aye, by my soul, there it lies, like my ould uncle, Dennis Kenrick, in Carrickfargus Church-yard: for we shall never see it again, as long as we live.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Good heavens! you alarm me!—surely the house hasn't fail'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: No, faith, the house stands an upright, just where it did, but the old thief of a banker, has'nt a thir∣teen left to bless himself with.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Broke!

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Aye, by my soul, broke horse and foot—and so bad, they say, that all the devils in hell can't mend him.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Then, indeed, I am completely ruined!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: (running to her.) No, don't you say so, Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Don't grieve! my sweet Miss Caroline, don't grieve! Och, the devil! my ould heart's as full as a bas∣ket of eggs. Pray now, keep up your spirits, for you have lost every farthing you have in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Oh, the Gracious! Is that it! Pray, if you please, Madam, don't take on so, then. For I have money.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: What have you money?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Aye, that I have: and while I have ten good pounds, that poor mother left me, in my box, and a silver watch, it shall never be said that I kept it from one in dis∣tress, who has been so kind to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Musha gra gal ma chree was you! what a pity it is now, that a generous heart has'nt always a heavy purse to keep it company.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: My poor girl! your grateful attachment touches me—I must retire and think of—do not follow me, Cecily—I'll consult on measures to—oh, providence! for what miseries am I ordained. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Dear, I hope I hav'nt given madam offence, by what I said?

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: No, my sweet one! you're a little angel in a mob cap.—What will I do now? there's my Watch and my Buckles, and my—by my soul now, I'd pawn my∣self if the pawnbroker would lend me any thing upon me—come with me and consult, little one.—Faith, I hav'nt a brother, or a nephew, or a cousin garman, or a father, or any (kiff or kin little bit of a kinsman) left to assist in all this botheration.—Come, little one? och! what an ould long winded beast am I, now, to have out-lived all my loving relations. [Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—A Chamber in an Inn.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Be more yourself, Henry. Firmness in the moment of disappointment—

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Disappointment!—'tis torture—it racks me—Caroline fled, none knows whither—unprotected! Per∣haps exposed to want too! to biting penury! The ac∣count, though confused, which I gathered last night from the unfeeling wretch in possession of the late Mr. Dor∣mer's house—why not have gone to my father's—Caroline might there have relied on an assylum.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Umph! perhaps not.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Oh, Stedfast! how little you know of my wor∣thy father's heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Yes, I've had a specimen.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Why did you prevent me from going to him last night?

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: After the ill news you had just received, at the late Mr. Dormer's, your mind was too much agitated for such an encounter.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Well, well; you see I followed your commands. You▪ rule me like a child, Stedfast; I went to bed, but not to rest—why should'nt you then, explain every thing?

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: You were unfit-to hear any thing. You were almost distracted. 'Twas sufficient that I sent word to Lord Duberly, that you would pay your duty to him, to∣day, after breakfast.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Well, you saw my father?

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: I did.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: And he received you with that complacency so friendly a messenger deserved.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Why to say the truth, I found none of that stately dignity about him, which you led me to expect.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P:
To you, of course, when you explained the pur∣port of your visit, he would throw that aside. The ten∣derness
of the father softened the austerity of habit, and his language came warm from the heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Upon my soul, 'twould puzzle me to tell where it came from: but to do him justice (notwithstand∣ing his harrangues in the House of Peers, which you talk'd of) his language was as little Parliamentary as any lan∣guage I ever heard in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Oh, your's was no meeting of formality.—Bu∣siness like your's called for no pomp of words on either side.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Words!—no—so his Lordship seemed to think, when he told me they buttered no parsnips.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: My father! You jest, sure?

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Indeed, I do not—and I'm afraid my dear young friend, your ardent feelings have painted the pa∣rental affection of Lord Duberly, in warmer colours than it merits.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Good Heaven! what do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: To be plain, he received the account of his lost son's arrival with more than coldness.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Oh, you mistook my dear father's manner.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Nothing could be less equivocal—He treated me with—but that does'nt signify—When I intro∣duced myself by informing him, that I came from Que∣bec—

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Aye; that must have excited his attention. He made a thousand enquiries?

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: No, faith. Only one.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: What was that?

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Pshaw!—trivial—merely ribaldry.—Damn it, I'm ashamed for his sake, and your's to mention it.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Nay, nay; I entreat you tell me.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Why he asked if—pshaw!—if I was a yan∣kee doodle, if you must have it.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: You astonish me.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Not more than I was astonished. In short, instead of finding the fond, anxious, agitated, father, I met a man reckless of his child's fate, and treating the man who brought him the news of a son's preservation with levity and insult.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Impossible! 'Tis not his nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Nay, even with buffoonery.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Take care, Stedfast—you may have miscon∣ceived; But I must not have my father's character made an ill-timed sport.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Nay, 'tis sportive enough in itself, for that matter.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Sportive!

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Yes, beyond comprehension. He deals in witchcraft, it seems;—for he was even jocular enough to tell me that he had a familiar in the shape of a Blue-boar, who had given him intelligence of your arrival. I confess, I was shocked.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: As I am Stedfast, shocked at your attempt in a moment like this, to trifle with the feelings of a friend, and endeavour to fully a venerable character, too well established to be tainted by the breath of misrepresenta∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Why, Zounds! I tell you that Lord Du∣berly—

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Lord Duberly, Sir, is as incapable of the con∣duct and language you have described, as I am incapable of hearing it without resentment.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Resentment! you are warm, Mr. Moreland.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: I have reason, Sir. Look at the man—Look at Lord Duberly—his very countenance contradicts the assertion.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Why, I dont know. I believed, since you said it, that gentleman was once written legibly on his brow—but damme, if time has'nt scratched out the writing, as thoroughly as ever writing was scratched out in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: This conduct of yours shall not go unpunished, Mr. Stedfast.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Unpunished, young man?

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: No, by Heaven! Such a gross aspersion of my good and worthy father, shall be answered with the life of that man—

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Who lately saved your's Henry.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Mr. Stedfast, I—I—

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Young man, 'tis well for us, that winter's enough have passed over my head, to make my blood flow in a temperate current.—Did it run riot like your's, we might now be cutting one another's throats.—Would it please you, think you, to have done me that office.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Please me! It makes me shudder.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Yet this, now, is what the world calls satis∣faction. I trust, I am as little daunted with big words, and a stern look, as most men. But the truest courage, Henry, is founded on reason:—and were the head oftner permitted to check the passions of the heart, there would be less fatal encounters, on foolish causes, and the peace of many a parent, wife and child might remain unbroken.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P:
Oh, Stedfast! The man that reasons thus would surely never mean to sport with my anxieties.—There
must be some mistake; pray pardon me, and accompany me to my father's. Assist me in unravelling this mystery which confounds me. Can you forgive my heart?

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: From the very bottom of my heart, Henry:—for, however rash in itself, the impulse was filial piety; and that with me will amply excuse it. [Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter DICK DOWLAS with DOCTOR PANGLOSS.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: It don't signify, Doctor; I can't rest 'till I have seen Cecily.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: What's a tutor's power over a pupil in love?—Annihilated.—True tho' trite, that, "Omina vinoie amor. Ovid.—Hem!—Is she pretty?

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: What's that to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Nothing. I'm dead to the fascinations of beauty since that unguarded day of dalliance, when being full of Bacchus.—"Bacchi plenus."—Horace.—Hem!—my pocket was picked of a metal watch, at the Sceptre, in Shoe-lane.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: This is the house. I've told you my story—and as you value my tree hundred a-year, Doctor, be ready to assist me, either by message, letter, or—but, what a damned gig you look like?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: A gig? Umpe! that's an Eaton phrase—the Westminster call it Quiz.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: And you are the greatest, sure, that ever was dispatched on love's embassies, from the court of cupid.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: I'm not proud of the post. Take my coun∣cil, and drop the pursuit. "Refrain, desist, desine."—Terence.—Hem▪

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Why, look'ye, doctor,—I've done an injury to two worthy souls; and I can't rest till I've made re∣paration. We are all of us wrong, at times, doctor, but a man doubles his ill-conduct, when he is too proud to make an apology for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Yet, confessing our faults, Mr. Dowlass—Dick D. Is only saying in other words, Doctor, that we were wiser to day, than we were yesterday.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Plenty of precedents, however, for your con∣duct—"At lovers perjuries they say—"

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Well, what do they say?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: "They say Jove laughs." Sheakspeare—Hem! Phaon left Sappho; Theseus, Ariadne, Demo∣phoon, Phyllis, Oneas, Dido.—

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Oh, Damn Dido.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Damn Dido?—Well, damn Dido?—with all my heart. She was daughter to King Belus of Tyre; but as very a virago—

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Well, we need not go so far for examples—now knock at that door? (Pointing to M. D.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Double?

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Zounds! no; you'll spoil all—a sneaking single tap, like a dun, doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Like a dun? I know the knock well, Mr. Dowlas.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: And when 'tis given, get out of the way for a while.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: My constant custom on such an occasion.—(Knocks, M. D.) There's the thorough thump of a cre∣ditor.—"I never heard it, but I ran away upon instinct." Shakespeare.—Hem! [Exit.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter CECILY, DICK is forward with his back towards her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Dear, sure somebody knock'd—I see nobody but that gentleman, neither—it could not be he, for if footman thump so loud, for certain, your gentlefolks must beat the door down—Was it you that knock'd, pray, Sir? (Dick turns round, Cecily screams.) Don't come near me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: My dear Cecily!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Oh, Dick, Dick! (cries and falls in his arms.)

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: I cannot bear this, your tears go to my very soul, Cecily.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: 'Tis you have been the cause of them, you have almost cut my poor heart in two.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: My own suffers for it sufficiently, believe me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: How could you be so barbarous to me? but, indeed, indeed, I forgive you.—Your cruelty will cost me many a tear, but this is the last time I shall ever upbraid you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Oh! I deserve all your reproaches.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: If I had come to fortune, and you had been poor, Dick, I would have flown to you, and cheered you in your poverty—I would have poured my gold at your feet; I would have shared all my joys with you, and told you, that riches could never change my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: And I come now, to share all mine with you, Cecily.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P:
Oh, no, Dick! my lot is very humble, but I scorn the gold that would buy my honesty. We must never, never, meet any more: but indeed, indeed, I do
truly wish you may be prosperous, though you sought my ruin. Bless you, Dick: and if ever poor Cecily comes into your mind, think that she pray to Heaven to forgive you, for trying to harm her innocence, whose greatest bles∣sing would have been, to make you happy (Going.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Stay, stay, and hear me; I entreat you, I come to sue your pardon—I come in repentance, Cecily.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: And do you repent?

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: I do; most earnestly.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: That is some comfort to me. For your own heart will be easier, and I shall bear my hard lot better, now. For I know your great friends will never let you stoop to one in my station. Ah! times are much changed with us, Dick!

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: However changed, they shall not now alter my purpose, Cecily, I have been dazzled, and I have wounded you, I have covered myself too, with shame and confu∣sion; but if they can make atonement, my fortune, my heart, and my hand, are all at your service.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Your hand! I,—I, shall be able to speak more soon—oh! Dick!

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: My dear, dear Cecily, I rose strangely to rank; and I shall, now, perhaps, in the eyes of the great world, strangely support it; for, I am afraid Cis, that half your young fellows of fashion, would rather seem wicked than ridiculous; but I shall never, for the future, think that marrying a worthy woman, whom chance has placed be∣neath us in life, can be any disgrace, while seducing her is reckoned among profligate fops, a matter of triumph.—Dry, dry your tears, Cecily.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: These are not like the tears I shed a while ago—they are tears of joy, Dick!—Hark! I am called.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: One moment,—tell me you forgive me?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Forgive you! Oh, Dick—you have made me happy! how this will comfort my poor Zekiel!

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: I shall be ashamed to meet him again, Cecily.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Oh, I will tell him all—and—hark! I'm called again.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Adien! I will see you very, very soon. Fare∣well!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Good bye—and—

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P:
Come, kiss—and—good bye. (Exit Cis.)—That one kiss of lovely virtue is worth a million of times more, than all the blandishments that wealth and luxury can purchase.—Where the devil, now, is this doctor? I am brimfull of joy, and I have nobody to communicate my—
Enter DOCTOR PANGLOSS. oh! you are returned—embrace me, doctor. Open wide your arms, in friendly congraulation and embrace, you prig of a tutor, the happiest fellow in christendom.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Bless me!—why we're in the middle of the street!—Decorum, Mr. Dowlas.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Damn decorum; I'm out of my senses.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Heaven forbid! for it would be as clear a nine hundred a year out of my pocket, as ever man lost in his life.—What's the news?

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: The news? why I am going to be married.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Married! mercy on me! Then he's mad, indeed—"Trbus anticyris caput insanable."—Horace.—Hem!—Consider the—

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Psha—I'v no time to—come—come with me to my father's—I'll explain to him—and—

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Only reflect—

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Reflect! look'ye here, you grave mustard-pot of a philosopher,—you shall dance a jig down the street with me, to shew your sympathy in my happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: A Doctor of Laws dance a jig in the open street!

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Foot it—"Over the hills and far away."

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: I wish you were far away, with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Dance—dance—or damn me I cut off your three hundred a year in a twinkling.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Will you?—oh, the—"a flourish of trum∣pets." Shakespeare—Hem!—"Over the hills and far away."—[Exit hand and hand, singing and dancing.

SP.SPEAKER: KENRICK.
SP.P:
TO be sure misfortune isn't a neat touchstone to try friendship upon. Faith, now, all my loving friends de∣serve a decent kicking; and, by my soul, I believe they expected it from my hands; for I no sonner said the word "lend"—but they all turned their backs to me. How my poor ould bones ache—and sure the biggest bone about me is in my heart, for that aches more than all the other half of my body. Och, my poor Miss Caroline what will I do, now your aground, to keep your pretty little chin above water! If we could have kept the brave
Mr. Henry Moreland's chin above water, now; but he's gone—he's gone; and twenty humane societies could'nt bring him back.—I'll make bold just to rest me a bit at this door. Don't be frightened, good gentleman within, for I an't coming to borrow any money from you. [Sits down at door.] Faith, this step is like my dear friends hearts; for, by St. Patrick. it's as could and hard as a hailstone.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Nay, nay be patient, Henry.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: My dear friend 'tis impossible. The blow is too great; so good so kind a father lost! and his death so strangely explained to me! indeed, indeed Stedfast, my spirit is almost broken.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: I can't see their faces, now, but sure these two must be a rich man that won't lend, and a borrower; for one is trotting about in great distress, and t'other as cool as a cucumber.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Come, come, Henry; the encounter was a strange one, 'tis true; and the shock sudden. When you entered a father's house, and prepared to leap into a fa∣ther's arms, to meet that low wretch, who has caused all our mistakes, was indeed—

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Oh, it distracts me! so many things are floating in my disordered mind; I—

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: But 'tis necessary you shou'd be collected, now, absolutely necessary. You must do speedy justice to your∣self▪ to the memory of your departed father. How came you not to discover yourself to that lump of ignorance, who has jump'd into your inheritance?

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: I was staggered; I heard enough from him to unravel all; and 'tis well perhaps, we withdrew so abruptly, I might have done something rash at the moment. Oh, Stedfast, I shall sink under it?

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: For shame, Henry! fye on this weakness! Sink under it! Decent sorrow for a near loss is amiable; and modest nature never looks more lovely, than when the filial tear steals gently on the tomb of a parent: but des∣perate grief outrages manhood and religion; for in the trials, which we all are born to undergo, Henry, the man and the christian forgets his duties to providence, and to himself, when he loses his resignation and his fortitude.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: You are an able and kind counsellor, my friend▪ I will endeavour to be more firm.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Come, let us go back to our hotel: you may there compose yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: (gets up) So, having taken a rest, I'll go home with my bad news to console poor Miss Caroline. (comes forward)

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: (seeing Kenrick.) I cannot be mistaken in that face—eh? Kenrick!

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Eh? why sure it can't be! sure my ould eyes are so bad, that I see what's invisible!

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: It is he! Oh, Kenrick! my good old man, tell me where is my Caroline?

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Och, faith it's himself, it's himself, it's him∣self!—safe, sound, and dry, without a wet rag about him!

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: But inform me, my honest Kenrick of—

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Hubbaboo! hubbaboo! och, I'll go wild! I'll go, mad! don't speak to me yet, my dear sweet Mr. Henry! och, good luck to the day when your honour walk'd ashore after you were drowned:

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: But tell me Kenrick, of—

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Yes—I'll tell you, I'll tell you of—och, up∣on my soul, you must wait abit: I believe I was drowned myself—for the salt-water runs out of my eyes by pail∣fulls.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Poor fellow!—an old servant of Mr. Dormer' I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Well now speak, Kenrick—oh, tell me is Ca∣roline safe?

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: In troth, and she is!

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Thank Heaven!—And in London?

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Yes, in this wide dirty town; and big as it is, there isn't a thirteen to be had, for love or money, to help her out of her distress.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Her distress! But I feared it. Let me fly to her; and—you are surely with her still, Kenrick?

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: With her! and is it yourself, Mr. Henry, that can ask Kenrick such a question? or would I leave my friends in their need, that supported me in their pros∣perity?—Och, the devil fly away with him that would I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P: Honest fellow!

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Pardon me, my good honest Kenrick.—I know not what I say, Conduct me to her, and you shall ex∣plain all by the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Conduct you! faith, ould as I am, I'll go hopping over all the kennels home with you, as nimble as a jack-daw.—Och, St. Patrick be praised.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Come then, Stedfast.

SP.SPEAKER: Stedfast.
SP.P:
Come, Henry. I'll see you to the door of Miss Dormer, and then leave you. And on this occasion, my dear friend, let me heartily congratulate you. Such an event as this, comes most opportunely; and it may
prove to you Henry, in this chequered life of joy and sorrow, that Providence has ever some balm in store to pour into the wounds that it inflicts; and that the worst of griefs may be assuaged by the pity power who chastens us! [Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: But listen, my lady, to reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Then I must'nt listen to you, My Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Um—why I've been almost scared out of my seven senses, for certain. The old man that was here last night, rushed in with another young one with him, this morning. I can't make head nor tail of what he wants for my part. But, as to Dick, he'll certainly break his heart, if he does'nt marry this here wench.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: I wonder, my Lord, you can think of such a thing—A Peer's son to marry a maid-servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Od rabbit it, my lady, now don't be obstra∣pulous. You know when his father married you, you was but a clear-starcher.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: That's quite another sort of an affair; and you might have more manners than to mention it now; but as to learning you elegance—ah! we may take the horse to the water, but there's no making him drink.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Nay, I'm sure I did'nt mean any disparage∣ment to you—for you was counted, on all hands, the best getter-up of small linen, in our town. Here's the doctor, let's ax his advice in this here business.—

DIV3.P: Pray now, doctor,—you must know we're in a bit of a quandiary, doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Your Lordship had better be in an uncertainty?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Why, lord love you, so I am, mum. Pray did'nt you never hear of no great man that was married to a farmer's daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Walter—a marquis of Lombardy—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: There, my lady! what do you think of that? damn it, if the Marquis smoused Grizzle, Dick may mary the maid servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: My pupil!—Zounds, my salary—"Tre∣mor occupat artus." Virgil—hem!—my income totters!—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: And in that there case, doctor, your three hundred a year, must go to the mending of my Cakelology.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: But I shall lose—no, thing:—a Lapsus linguoe.—One annuity gone with my pupil! Then I've only "clear for life, six hundred pounds a year" Swift.—Hem!—Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: (Apart to Pangloss.) You know, Doctor, my three hnndred stops, the moment my son marries.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Does it? Oh, Jupiter, if ever contradiction crept into the bosom of beauteous woman—"Mulier sor∣mosa." Horace.—Hem!—Stuff a double dose into that ter∣rible old woman, and save the fortunes of Peter Pangloss. Here he comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Well, father, has my mother made up her mind?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Why, I can't tell Dick.—my lady seems be∣twixt and betweenish, as a body may say. But it all de∣pends upon her vardick.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Well, she is but a farmer's daughter, they say, and what's a farmer, my dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Why, an English farmer, mother, is one who supports his family and serves his country, by his own industry in this land of commerce.—Mother, such a cha∣racter will be always respectable.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: That's right, Dick—Father's own son to a hair. When I kept my sop at Gosport, I—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Hush my lord.—Well you—you wre always my darling, you know, Dick; and, I can't find in my heart to give you a denial.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Can't you! I wish you could find it in your tongue.—Six hundred a year, blown away by the breath of that Sybyl.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: That's my good mother, you've made me so happy, I, zounds, I shall run mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Zounds! and so shall I.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: A thousand thanks, my dear mother, and my dear father, too; I'll get as drunk as—wish me joy, Doctor—wish me joy a hundred times!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: A hundred times!—I feel, Mr. Dowlass, on this occasion, six hundred times more than I know how to express.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: And if you would but indulge me now, in let∣ting me conduct you to Cecily—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Odd rot it, my Lady, let's humour Dick for once. The young ones like to be cooing and buiding, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Why the coach, I believe, is at the door, my lord. [Exit with Lord Duberly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Is it? hobs then, my lady, let' bundle, Dick,—come Doctor—Now you mus'nt make me ride backwards, my lady,—for you know I ha'nt been used to a coach, and I shall certainly be qualmish if you do.—Come my lady!—

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Come, Doctor, we lose time?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Time!—lose!—I've lost as pretty a pair of snug annuities as—let me see—"Take six from nine."—

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Why, Doctor?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: "And three remains." Cocker.—Hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Come, come—it's late?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Only three?

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Only three! why it's only twelve, man; but come, if you don't attend to my father better, I can tell you he'll kick you and your three hundred a year to the devil.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Will he?—"Oh, for a house with wings?"—Shakespeare—Hem!—I fly, Mr. Dowlas.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Indeed, I truly hope you are better, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: I have little reason to be so, Cecily.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Oh, I hope you have! and if the worst comes to the worst—but I'm almost asham'd to tell you, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Innocence, like yours, my good girl, can know nothing it should fear to reveal.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Why, I needn't be much afraid, neither—for it's what a power of folks, rich and poor, do come to at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: What's that, Cecily?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Wedlock, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Indeed! this is unexpected, after what you told me this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Aye, but you know, Madam, as to wedlock, and all that, many things fall out between the cup and the lip, as they say.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: (sighing.) 'Tis too true, indeed, Cecily.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: And so my Dick came to our door, Madam; 'tis but a little while agone—and his dear eyes were as full of tears! and you know that was a pity, Madam—for his eyes are so fine and so blue, 'tis a shame any thing should spoil 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Well, Cecily?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: And so we soon brought matters to bear, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: How, Cecily?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P:
Why he looked so sorry that it made my heart bleed to see him—and when I love him so dearly, it would
be cruel not to marry him when he asked me. Don't you think so, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: May you be very, very happy!—'tis an ease to my mind, in the midst of my misfortunes, to know that you will be provided for. I was on the point of tel∣ling you, Cecily, that my reduced circumstances would not permit me to keep you with me any longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Oh, dear! and was you going to be so un∣kind to me, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Unkind to you my good girl! oh, no! it would have to have sent forth simplicity like yours, unpro∣tected.—But hard necessity!—I rejoice my good Cecily, rejoice sincerely in your good fortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Oh, Madam! I should rejoice more at my good fortune, if you would but let me do what I've been thinking on.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: What is that, Cecily?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: I hope you won't be angry at what I'm going to say, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Oh, impossible! speak freely.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Why, you know, Madam, Dick's a lord's son; and when I am his wife, I may do fast as I please, for rich folks wives, I have heard say, do just what they please in London.—Now, if you would but be so good, when I'm married, as to let me serve you for nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: No more, no more, Cecily;—I—

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: And when my husband gives me any money, if you would be but so kind as o borrow it of me, I should be very much obliged to you, indeed, Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Oh! you have overpowered me. (falls on Ce∣cily's neck.) Oh, Heaven!—how pure are all thy creatures endowed with reason, 'till worldly habits corrupt them!

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: What is that?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: 'Twas brother Zekiel's voice, sure.—He can't think to make such a noise here!

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Tol, de rol, lol, lol!—Tol, lol, de rol, lol, lol?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Mercy, Zekiel!—why you must be crazy, sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Zooks! and so I be, sister.—Tol, lol, de rol?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Think where you are, brother.—There's Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P:
Rabbit it, Madam, I do most humbly crave pardon—but I be in such flustration!—I ha' got—I ha'
got—Tol, de rol, lol!—I ha' got Twenty Thousand Pounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: My gracious! Twenty Thousand Pounds:

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Tol, lol, de rol, lol!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: But stand still, now, brother Zekiel—where did you get such a sight of money?

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: I' the lottery, lass!—i'he lottery.—Let me take a bit of breath.—I do crave pardon, madam.—Fa∣ther's ticket—let me take a bit of—have come a prize of—a bit of breath—dear, dear, madam, heaven send this luck do not set my simple brain a madding.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Compose yourself, honest friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: I do humbly thank you, madam.—I ha'—run all the way—from Lottery Office, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Well, and what will you do with all this money, Zekiel?

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: What will I do wi' it, Sister Cecily! Why what should a man do wi' his riches? I will first provide for such as I do love, and then, lend a helping hand to them as be poor about me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Dear brother, that's just the thing!—Come here, Zekiel—poor Madam has fallen into great trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Has she?—How?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Why all her friends are dead it seems.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Poor soul!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: And her banker hole all the money she had, this very morning, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Don't ye say any more, sister Cecily, hum!—madam—I—I be main glad to hear you be tumbled into misfortune—madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Glad, friend!

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Main glad, indeed! because you ha' been so kind to sister—and I be able now to return you the favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Oh, no more of that, Zekiel—you distress me.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: With submission, Madam, I want to take away your distress. Here, Madam—[pulling out bank notes.]—Here be a hundred—and there be a five hundred—and there be a—Rabbit it! my hand do shake too much to stand counting. I will spread 'em all upon a table here—Take what you do want, Madam, and welcome; and thank you too, Madam.
SP.STAGE: [spreading them on the table in a grat flurry.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: I cannot—I cannot think friend, of—(Both.) Pray ye do, now, Madam—pray ye do!

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Bless me,—who's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Beg pardon, Madam, but the landlady bid u bundle up,

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Your commands with me, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Why the whole preamble of this affair is, that my Lady and I—speak to the gentlewoman my lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Ah, you have a head, and so has a pin.—We made bold to pay our respects, madam, having a little business concerning a female of your family.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Yes, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: To whom have I the honour of speaking, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Why, you've the honour of speaking to Lord Duberly, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: What! (gathers up the Notes hastily, and comes forward.)

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: To Lord Duberly!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: But Dick's coming up, with Dr. Pangloss hard at his heels, and they'll tell you the long and the short on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: What, Dick Dowlas;—Then you be the old chandler they ha' made a lord on?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Old chandler, indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Look ye, my lord Soap and candles—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Soap and Candles!

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Your son had better keep clear o' me, I can tell him that.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter DOCTOR PANGLOSS and DICK DOWLAS.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Cecily, let me—

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Stand off, Mr. Dowlas! stand off▪—to think to come here to—od rabbit it! my fingers do itch to be at you. Keep you behind me, sister Cecily.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: My dear Zekiel, I—

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Don't you hear me? I put little trust in fair words with foul actions.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Dear now, you are so hasty, Zekiel!

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Hold your peace, Cecily. The best he that ever wore a head, had better be hanged than venture to harm you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Cecily I find has not explained. I'm here Ze∣kiel, to make reparation.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: You ha' stung me to the quick, you know you have.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: I share with you in all the pain, Zekiel, which I have so wantonly inflicted; my heart smote me, even before you left me; and every little reflection convinced me, that in the vanity of sudden fortune, I had offered you and the woman of my heart, a bitter injury. I am thought∣less, Zekiel, but not deliberately base; and, if you can, once more take to your bosom, a guilty, but repentant friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Oh, Dick, Dick! (runs and embraces him.) my old companion! ah, Dick, that be a stony bosom that can shut out an old friend, that be truly grieved for his faults, and do sue for mercy.—It be more than I can do.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Dear, I'm so happy!

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: You have made my heart many a pound the lighter, Dick.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: And my own, too, Zekiel; and to prove my sincerity, my father and mother here, are come with an offer of my hand to Cecily.—Father—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Why, my Lady here, is a little upon the grumpy order for his calling us chandlers. But for my part, I don't value that of a button. A man needn't take no affront to be told he was born low, when he has got better in the world without no dishonesty.—There, chil∣dren, be happy together.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Why now, that's hearty, and as luck be apt to turn wi' us along—why I ha' gotten twenty thousand pounds, and I warrant Cecily shall ha' some'at handsome, toss'd in at the wedding.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Twenty thousand pounds!—[goes forward to Zekiel.] Sir, as you will now need a tutor, to usher you into life, three hundred per annum, are the trifling terms of your obedient servant, Peter Pangloss, L. L. D. and A. double S.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily H.
SP.P: Aye, all in the lottery—I'll tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Stand out of the way! He's coming, my dear Miss Caroline, he's coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Who, Kenrick?

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: 'Tis himself! 'tis himself—he'e alive, and leaping up stairs, like a salmon out of the water.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Who do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: My dear, young, lost master; 'tis Mr. Henry himself, madam.—

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: My Henry! Oh support me. (faints)

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: My Caroline! oh, let me clasp you to my heart, and shelter you there for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Why, zounds! that's the young suckling madman as scared me out of my senses with the old one, this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: O bless 'em both! may they live to be happy to the end of the world, and a thousand years after it.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: (recovering.) This is too much! oh, Hen∣ry! do we once more meet! and after—by what miracle have you escaped?

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.P: Be satisfied ma'am, for he's too much bother'd to talk. But you see he's here, and that's enough—the true, long lost, Mr. Henry Moreland.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Eh? what? Henry Moreland! Why, zounds! the late Lord Duberly's lost heir!

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Son and heir to that revered and respected man, be assured Sir. You have done me the favour to be my tocum tenens in my absence, and I am now return'd to re∣lieve you from further trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Why, what the devil! have I only been a kind of peer's warming-pan after all—just pop'd in to keep his place from getting cold, 'till he jump'd into it.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Nothing more, believe me. I have witnesses sufficient, should it be necessary to identify my person in a minute.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Od rabbit it, then old Daniel Dowlas is no longer a Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Nor Deborah Dowlas, a Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Nor Dick Dowlas an Honourable.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: Nor Peter Pangloss a tutor.—"Now, thank Heaven—"

DIV3.STAGE: "That I'm not worth a ducat." Otway.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Then it do seem at last, Dick, that I be the rich man, and you the poor, od rabbit it! I be glad on't! for I can now please myself wi' serving my friends.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Who is this, my Caroline?

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: An honest creature, Henry.—Brother to this simple girl.—Their affection to me in my distress, has been most piercing.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: Then it shall not go unrewarded, my Caroline.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: Wi' humble submission, Sir, kindness to a fellow creature in distress do reward itself.—Thanks to the Lottery, we be rich, enow.—But as Dick Dowlas be to marry Cecily, if you would just lend me a helping hand, for his father and mother here.—

SP.SPEAKER: More
SP.P: Oh rest contented, honest friend, I shall not dis∣possess them without making a proper provision.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: My Lord.—Hem!—(To Henry.)—if a boy should bless your nuptials, which is now shortly to take place, he will certainly require a tutor.—Three hundred per annum are the terms of your Lordship's obsequious servant, Peter Pangloss, E. E. D. and A, double S.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: You are not one of those, Sir, it seems who lose an appointment for want of an early application for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: The human mind, my lord, naturally looks forward,—"anum us pactviuet fultura," Cicero—Hem.

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: If I should need such a person, Sir, depend upon it, I should be very particular in my choice—for I suspect there are some amongst those to whom youth is entrusted who bring the character of a tutor into isrepute—and draw ridicule upon a respectable situation, in which many men of learning and probity are placed.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Pan.
SP.P: This will never do for me. Again must I retire to Milk-alley, and spin my brain for subsistence. "Panglos's occupations gone!"—Shakespeare—Hem!

SP.SPEAKER: More.
SP.P: In calmer moments, my Caroline, I will explain the circumstances of my preservation, and when I have paid the mournful tribute due to a much lamented father, let me call you mine, and place you above the reach of fu∣ture sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.P: Little sorrow can reach me, when you are safe, Henry.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel H.
SP.P: And we'll get into the country—Take a bit of a farm—and all be as merry as grigs, Dick.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick D.
SP.P: Agreed, Zekiel, come Cecily, I have seen enough already of splendour, to seek for happiness in qui∣eter scenes, and I have learn't, Zekiel, that, in spite of all the allurements which riches or titles may boast—the most solid and valuable possession, is, a true friend.—

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE.
TO BE Spoken by the Characters.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick Dowlas.
SP.L: Custom enacts, and who denies her sway,
An Epilogue to every five act play.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor Panglos.
SP.L: You speak it then—and do not mouth it, come,
Yet be not too tame neither—Shakespear—Hum!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Duberly.
SP.L: Rabbit it! best let these logs alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Duberly
SP.L: What Epilogues—why they are all the ton.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel.
SP.L: What be these Epilogues your'e talking on.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor Panglos.
SP.L: Epi and Logos—Vide Lexicon.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.L: I'll tell you, honey, Epilogues, they say,
Are what are always spoke before the play,
By some good-looking gentleman well drest.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecily.
SP.L: Oh! then, I am sure my Dick will speak 'em best.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry Moreland.
SP.L: To win the town the Epilogues intends,
And the play over, please our best of friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel.
SP.L: Please our best friends, that's hearty sure and right.
I spy a power here we fain would please to night.—
Who▪ll try?—

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.L: I.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor Panglos
SP.L: And I.—

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.L: We're of one mind, had there be twenty 'tis car∣ried.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor Panglos.
SP.L: Nemine Dissentiente.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.L: Thus to begin then:—
If here some thoughtless younker may be found,
In fashions giddy vortex whirling round,
May he to night from Dick's example see,
That honor's real prop—is honesty,—
May reformation's pledge his cheek o▪ercast,
The self-accusing blush for errors past▪

SP.SPEAKER: Cicily.
SP.L: If there's a ass in love here, ye, spied her,
Sitting quite close with that young man beside her,
Let her, like Cecily, to this maxim cling,
Love slights all gold—except the Wedding Ring.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Duberly.
SP.L: Is there ne'er a chandler here—because—
Old Daniel Dowlas axes his applause.
SP.STAGE: [Lady Duberly taps him on the shoulder.
SP.L: Why, zounds—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Duberly.
SP.L: What—will you never stop,

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Duberly.
SP.L: I'm only axing custom for the shop.

SP.SPEAKER: Moreland.
SP.L: While filial duty animates each youth,
While virtuous passions warms the heart of truth,
With qualities like these to Britons dear,
Henry may surely hope for favour here.

SP.SPEAKER: Caroline.
SP.L: And may not Caroline applause secure,
Who to all these adds feeling for the poor.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenrick.
SP.L: Oh bother, there's so many virtues ,
There won't be any lest for me, I fear;
Burn him who leaves, I can't say more or less,
A patron, friend▪ or female in distress

SP.SPEAKER: Zekiel.
SP.L: your fist, that's hearty now and fair,
You be of Zekiel's kidney to a hair.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor Panglos.
SP.L: Does any body want a tutor here,
My terms are but—three hundred pounds a-year
On their own merits modest men are dumb—
Plaudite et Valere.—Terence—Hum!—
Then on my merits I shall lay no stress,
I'm L. L. D. and—and A. Double S.
